[The man]1397-the man drew out paper and tobacco and twirled the one up in the other with surprising dexterity . [He]1397-the man had long , quivering fin- gers as agile and restless as the antennae of an insect .

[Holmes]96-holmes was silent , but [his]96-holmes little darting glances showed [me]0-i the interest which [he]96-holmes took in [[our]206-our curious companion]209-our curious companion .

" [I]96-holmes presume , [sir]1459-sir , "[96-holmes] said [he]96-holmes at last , " that it was not merely for the purpose of examining [my]96-holmes skull that [you]1459-sir have done [me]96-holmes the honour to call [here]1456-here last night and again to - day ? "[96-holmes]

" No , [sir]1459-sir , no ; though [I]96-holmes am happy to have had the opportunity of doing that as well . [I]96-holmes came to [you]1459-sir , [Mr. Holmes]96-holmes , because [I]96-holmes recognized that [I]96-holmes am [myself]96-holmes [an unpractical man]1485-an unpractical man and because [I]96-holmes am suddenly confronted with a most serious and extraordinary prob- lem . Recognizing , as [I]96-holmes do , that [you]1459-sir are [the second highest expert in [Europe]9-europe]1486-the second highest expert in europe - "[96-holmes]

" Indeed , [sir]1459-sir ! May [I]96-holmes inquire who has the honour to be the first ? "[96-holmes] asked [Holmes]96-holmes with some asperity .

" To [the man of precisely scientific mind]1488-the man of precisely scientific mind the work of [Mon- sieur Bertillon]99-mon- sieur bertillon must always appeal strongly . "[96-holmes]

" Then had [you]96-holmes not better consult [him]99-mon- sieur bertillon ? "[96-holmes]

" Just a little , "[96-holmes] said [Holmes]96-holmes . " [I]96-holmes think , [Dr. Mortimer]94-dr. mortimer , [you]94-dr. mortimer would do wisely if without more ado [you]94-dr. mortimer would kindly tell [me]96-holmes plainly what the exact nature of the problem is in which [you]94-dr. mortimer demand [my]96-holmes assistance . Chapter 2

The Curse of [the Baskervilles]92-the baskervilles

" [I]94-dr. mortimer have in [my]94-dr. mortimer pocket a manuscript , "[94-dr. mortimer] said [Dr. James Mortimer]94-dr. mortimer .

" [I]96-holmes observed it as [you]94-dr. mortimer entered [the room]201-the room , "[96-holmes] said [Holmes]96-holmes .

" It is an old manuscript . "[96-holmes]

" Early eighteenth century , unless it is a forgery . "[94-dr. mortimer]

" How can [you]1459-sir say that , [sir]1459-sir ? "[96-holmes]

" [You]94-dr. mortimer have presented an inch or two of it to [my]94-dr. mortimer examination all the time that [you]94-dr. mortimer have been talking . It would be [a poor expert who could not give the date of a document within a decade or so]1494-a poor expert who could not give the date of a document within a decade or so . [You]94-dr. mortimer may possibly have read [my]94-dr. mortimer little monograph upon the subject . [I]94-dr. mortimer put that at 1730 . "[94-dr. mortimer]

" The exact date is 1742 . "[96-holmes] [Dr. Mortimer]94-dr. mortimer drew it from [his]94-dr. mortimer breast - pocket . " This family paper was committed to [my]94-dr. mortimer care by [Sir Charles Baskerville]100-sir charles , whose sudden and tragic death some three months ago created so much excitement in [Devonshire]10-devonshire . [I]94-dr. mortimer may say that [I]94-dr. mortimer was [[his]100-sir charles personal friend]1495-his personal friend as well as [[his]100-sir charles medical attendant]1496-his medical attendant . [He]100-sir charles was [a strong - minded man]1497-a strong - minded man , [sir]1459-sir , shrewd , practical , and as unimaginative as [I]94-dr. mortimer am [myself]94-dr. mortimer . Yet [he]100-sir charles took this document very seriously , and [his]100-sir charles mind was prepared for just such an end as did eventually overtake [him]100-sir charles . "[94-dr. mortimer]

[Holmes]96-holmes stretched out [his]96-holmes hand for the manuscript and flattened it upon [his]96-holmes knee .

" [You]0-i will observe , [Watson]95-watson , the alternative use of the long s and the short . It is one of several indications which enabled [me]96-holmes to fix the date . "[96-holmes]

[I]0-i looked over [his]96-holmes shoulder at the yellow paper and the faded script . At the head was written : " [Baskerville Hall]115-sir henry , "[0-i] and below in large , scrawling figures : " 1742 . "[0-i]

" It appears to be a statement of some sort . "[0-i]

" Yes , it is a statement of a certain legend which runs in [the Baskerville family]1499-the baskerville family . "[0-i]

" But [I]0-i understand that it is something more modern and practical upon which [you]96-holmes wish to consult [me]0-i ? "[0-i]

" Most modern . A most practical , pressing matter , which must be decided within twenty - four hours . But the manuscript is short and is intimately connected with the affair . With [your]0-i permission [I]0-i will read it to [you]0-i . "[0-i]

[Holmes]96-holmes leaned back in [his]96-holmes chair , placed [his]96-holmes finger - tips to- gether , and closed [his]96-holmes eyes , with an air of resignation . [Dr. Mortimer]94-dr. mortimer turned the manuscript to the light and read in a high , cracking voice the following curious , old - world narrative :

" Of the origin of [the Hound of [the Baskervilles]92-the baskervilles]1500-the hound of the baskervilles there have been many statements , yet as [I]94-dr. mortimer come in a direct line from [Hugo Baskerville]101-hugo , and as [I]94-dr. mortimer had the story from [[my]94-dr. mortimer father]1501-my father , who also had it from [his]1501-my father , [I]94-dr. mortimer have set it down with all belief that it occurred even as is here set forth . And [I]94-dr. mortimer would have [you]0-i believe , [[my]94-dr. mortimer sons]1502-my sons , that the same Justice which punishes sin may also most graciously forgive it , and that no ban is so heavy but that by prayer and repentance it may be removed . Learn then from this story not to fear the fruits of the past , but rather to be circumspect in the future , that those foul passions whereby [[our]1503-our family]1504-our family has suffered so grievously may not again be loosed to [our]1503-our undoing . Know then that in the time of the Great Rebellion the history of which by the learned [Lord Clarendon]102-lord clarendon [I]94-dr. mortimer most earnestly commend to [your]0-i attention [this Manor of [Basker- ville]124-basker- ville]1505-this manor of basker- ville was held by [Hugo]101-hugo of that name , nor can it be gainsaid that [he]101-hugo was [a most wild , profane , and godless man]1506-a most wild , profane , and godless man . This , in truth , [[his]101-hugo neighbours]1507-his neighbours might have pardoned , seeing that [saints]1508-saints have never flourished in those parts , but there was in [him]101-hugo a certain wanton and cruel humour which made [his]101-hugo name a by- word through [the West]1509-the west . It chanced that [this Hugo]101-hugo came to love if , indeed , so dark a passion may be known under so bright a name [the daughter of [a yeoman who held lands near [the Baskerville estate]1512-the baskerville estate]1511-a yeoman who held lands near the baskerville estate]1510-the daughter of a yeoman who held lands near the baskerville estate . But [the young maiden , being discreet and of good repute]1513-the young maiden , being discreet and of good repute , would ever avoid [him]101-hugo , for [she]1513-the young maiden , being discreet and of good repute feared [his]101-hugo evil name . So it came to pass that [one [Michaelmas]103-michaelmas [this Hugo]1515-this hugo , with five or six of [his]101-hugo idle and wicked compan- ions]1514-one michaelmas this hugo , with five or six of his idle and wicked compan- ions , stole down upon [the farm]1516-the farm and carried off [the maiden]1517-the maiden , [[her]1517-the maiden father]1518-her father and [brothers]1519-brothers being from [home]1520-home , as [he]101-hugo well knew . When [they]1519-brothers had brought [her]1517-the maiden to [the Hall]1521-the hall [the maiden]1517-the maiden was placed in [an upper chamber]1523-an upper chamber , while [Hugo]101-hugo and [[his]101-hugo friends]1422-his friends sat down to a long carouse , as was [their]1519-brothers nightly custom . Now , [the poor lass]1525-the poor lass upstairs was like to have [her]1525-the poor lass wits turned at the singing and shouting and terrible oaths which came up to [her]1525-the poor lass from below , for [they]1519-brothers say that the words used by [Hugo Baskerville]101-hugo , when [he]101-hugo was in wine , were such as might blast [the man who said them]1526-the man who said them . At last in the stress of [her]1525-the poor lass fear [she]1525-the poor lass did that which might have daunted [the bravest or most active man]1527-the bravest or most active man , for by the aid of the growth of ivy which covered and still covers the south wall [she]1525-the poor lass came down from under the eaves , and so homeward across [the moor]1528-the moor , there being three leagues betwixt [the Hall]1521-the hall and [[[her]1525-the poor lass father]1518-her father 's farm]1531-her father 's farm . It chanced that some little time later [Hugo]101-hugo left [[his]101-hugo guests]1532-his guests to carry food and drink - with other worse things , perchance - to [[his]101-hugo captive]1533-his captive , and so found the cage empty and the bird escaped . Then , as it would seem , [he]101-hugo became as one that hath [a devil]1534-a devil , for , rushing down the stairs into [the dining - hall]1535-the dining - hall , [he]101-hugo sprang upon the great table , flagons and trenchers flying before [him]101-hugo , and [he]101-hugo cried aloud before all the company that [he]101-hugo would that very night render [his]101-hugo body and soul to the Powers of Evil if [he]101-hugo might but overtake [the wench]1536-the wench . And while [the revellers]1537-the revellers stood aghast at the fury of [the man]1397-the man , one more wicked or , it may be , more drunken than [the rest]1539-the rest , cried out that [they]1537-the revellers should put the hounds upon [her]1533-his captive Whereat [Hugo]101-hugo ran from [the house]1540-the house , crying to [[his]101-hugo grooms]1541-his grooms that [they]1537-the revellers should saddle [his]101-hugo mare and unkennel the pack , and giving the hounds a kerchief of [the maid]1542-the maid 's , [he]101-hugo swung [them]1537-the revellers to the line , and so off full cry in the moonlight over [the moor]1528-the moor . Now , for some space [the revellers]1537-the revellers stood agape , unable to understand all that had been done in such haste . But anon [their]1537-the revellers bemused wits awoke to the nature of the deed which was like to be done upon [the moorlands]1545-the moorlands . Everything was now in an uproar , [some]1546-some calling for [their]1546-some pistols , some for [their]1546-some horses , and some for another flask of wine . But at length some sense came back to [their]1537-the revellers crazed minds , and [the whole of [them]1537-the revellers]1547-the whole of them , thirteen in number , took horse and started in pursuit . The moon shone clear above [them]1537-the revellers , and [they]1537-the revellers rode swiftly abreast , taking that course which [the maid]1542-the maid must needs have taken if [she]1542-the maid were to reach [[her]1542-the maid own home]1549-her own home . [They]1537-the revellers had gone a mile or two when [they]1537-the revellers passed one of [the night shepherds]1550-the night shepherds upon [the moorlands]1545-the moorlands , and [they]1537-the revellers cried to [him]1552-he to know if [he]1552-he had seen the hunt . And [the man]1397-the man , as the story goes , was so crazed with fear that [he]1552-he could scarce speak , but at last [he]1552-he said that [he]1552-he had indeed seen [the unhappy maiden]1554-the unhappy maiden , with the hounds upon [her]1554-the unhappy maiden track . ' But [I]94-dr. mortimer have seen more than that , ' said [he]94-dr. mortimer , ' for [Hugo Baskerville]101-hugo passed [me]94-dr. mortimer upon [his]101-hugo black mare , and there ran mute behind [him]101-hugo such a hound of hell as [God]104-god forbid should ever be at [my]94-dr. mortimer heels . ' So [the drunken squires]1555-the drunken squires cursed [the shepherd]1556-the shepherd and rode onward . But soon [their]1555-the drunken squires skins turned cold , for there came a galloping across [the moor]1528-the moor , and [the black mare , dabbled with white froth]1558-the black mare , dabbled with white froth , went past with trailing bridle and empty saddle . Then [the revellers]1537-the revellers rode close together , for a great fear was on [them]1537-the revellers , but [they]1537-the revellers still followed over [the moor]1528-the moor , though [each]1561-each , had [he]1561-each been alone , would have been right glad to have turned [his]1561-each horse 's head . Riding slowly in this fashion [they]1537-the revellers came at last upon the hounds . [These]1562-their , though known for [their]1562-their valour and [their]1562-their breed , were whim- pering in a cluster at the head of [a deep dip or goyal]1563-a deep dip or goyal , as [we]1564-we call it , upon [the moor]1528-the moor , [some]1546-some slinking away and some , with starting hackles and staring eyes , gazing down [the narrow valley before [them]1537-the revellers]1567-the narrow valley before them . [The company]1568-the company had come to a halt , [more sober men]1569-more sober men , as [you]1570-you may guess , than when [they]1537-the revellers started . The most of [them]1537-the revellers would by no means advance , but three of [them]1537-the revellers , [the boldest , or it may be the most drunken]1571-the boldest , or it may be the most drunken , rode forward down [the goyal]1572-the goyal . Now , [it]1572-the goyal opened into a broad space in which stood two of those great stones , still to be seen there , which were set by [certain forgotten peoples in the days of old]1573-certain forgotten peoples in the days of old . The moon was shining bright upon [the clearing]1574-the clearing , and there in the centre lay [the unhappy maid]1575-the unhappy maid where [she]1575-the unhappy maid had fallen , dead of fear and of fatigue . But it was not the sight of [her]1575-the unhappy maid body , nor yet was it that of the body of [Hugo Baskerviile]105-hugo baskerviile lying near [her]1575-the unhappy maid , which raised the hair upon the heads of [these three dare- devil roysterers]1576-these three dare- devil roysterers , but it was that , standing over [Hugo]105-hugo baskerviile , and plucking at [his]105-hugo baskerviile throat , there stood a foul thing , a great , black beast , shaped like a hound , yet larger than any hound that ever mortal eye has rested upon . And even as [they]1576-these three dare- devil roysterers looked the thing tore the throat out of [Hugo Baskerville]101-hugo , on which , as it turned its blazing eyes and dripping jaws upon [them]1576-these three dare- devil roysterers , [the three]1577-the three shrieked with fear and rode for dear life , still screaming , across [the moor]1528-the moor . [One]106-one , it is said , died that very night of what [he]106-one had seen , and [the other twain]1579-the other twain were but [broken men]1580-broken men for the rest of [their]1579-the other twain days . Such is the tale , [[my]94-dr. mortimer sons]1502-my sons , of the coming of the hound which is said to have plagued [the family]1582-the family so sorely ever since . If [I]94-dr. mortimer have set it down it is because that which is clearly known hath less terror than that which is but hinted at and guessed . Nor can it be denied that [many of [the family]1582-the family]1583-many of the family have been unhappy in [their]1583-many of the family deaths , which have been sudden , bloody , and mysterious . Yet may [we]1585-we shelter [ourselves]1585-we in the infinite goodness of [Providence]107-providence , which would not for- ever punish [the innocent]1586-the innocent beyond that third or fourth genera- tion which is threatened in Holy Writ . To that Providence , [[my]94-dr. mortimer sons]1502-my sons , [I]94-dr. mortimer hereby commend [you]1502-my sons , and [I]94-dr. mortimer counsel [you]1502-my sons by way of caution to forbear from crossing [the moor]1528-the moor in those dark hours when the powers of evil are exalted . This from [Hugo Baskerville]101-hugo to [[his]101-hugo sons]1589-his sons [Rodger]108-rodger and [John]109-john , with instructions that [they]1589-his sons say nothing thereof to [[their]1589-his sons sister]1590-their sister [Elizabeth]110-elizabeth . " Now , [Mr. Holmes]96-holmes , [we]212-we will give [you]96-holmes something a little more recent . This is the Devon County Chronicle of May 14th of this year . [[My]0-i friend]1476-my friend leaned a little forward and [his]1476-my friend expression became intent . [[Our]212-we visitor]187-our visitor readjusted [his]1476-my friend glasses and began :

" The recent sudden death of [Sir Charles Baskerville]100-sir charles ,[187-our visitor]

whose name has been mentioned as [the probable Liberal

candidate for [Mid - Devon]13-mid - devon]214-the probable liberal candidate for mid - devon at the next election , has cast a

gloom over [the county]215-the county . Though [Sir Charles]100-sir charles had resided at

[Baskerville Hall]115-sir henry for a comparatively short period [his]100-sir charles amia-

bility of character and extreme generosity had won the

affection and respect of [all who had been brought into

contact with [him]100-sir charles]216-all who had been brought into contact with him . In these days of nouveaux riches it is

refreshing to find a case where [the scion of [an old county

family which has fallen upon evil days]218-an old county family which has fallen upon evil days]217-the scion of an old county family which has fallen upon evil days is able to make [his]217-the scion of an old county family which has fallen upon evil days

own fortune and to bring it back with [him]217-the scion of an old county family which has fallen upon evil days to restore the

fallen grandeur of [[his]217-the scion of an old county family which has fallen upon evil days line]219-his line . [Sir Charles]100-sir charles , as is well known ,

made large sums of money in South African speculation .

More wise than those who go on until the wheel turns

against [them]220-them , [he]100-sir charles realized [his]100-sir charles gains and returned to [England]14-england

with [them]220-them . It is only two years since [he]100-sir charles took up [his]100-sir charles resi-

dence at [Baskerville Hall]115-sir henry , and it is common talk how large

were those schemes of reconstruction and improvement which

have been interrupted by [his]100-sir charles death . Being [himself]100-sir charles childless ,

it was [his]100-sir charles openly expressed desire that [the whole country-

side]221-the whole country- side should , within [his]100-sir charles own lifetime , profit by [his]100-sir charles good

fortune , and many will have personal reasons for bewailing

[his]100-sir charles untimely end . [His]100-sir charles generous donations to local and [county

charities]222-county charities have been frequently chronicled in these columns .

" The circumstances connected with the death of [Sir Charles]100-sir charles[100-sir charles]

can not be said to have been entirely cleared up by the

inquest , but at least enough has been done to dispose of

those rumours to which local superstition has given rise .

There is no reason whatever to suspect foul play , or to

imagine that death could be from any but natural causes . [Sir

Charles]100-sir charles was [a widower]223-a widower , and [a man who may be said to have

been in some ways of an eccentric habit of mind]224-a man who may be said to have been in some ways of an eccentric habit of mind . In spite of

[his]100-sir charles considerable wealth [he]100-sir charles was simple in [his]100-sir charles personal tastes ,

and [bis indoor servants at [Baskerville Hall]115-sir henry]225-bis indoor servants at baskerville hall consisted of [a mar-

ried couple named [Barrymore]111-barrymore , [the husband]227-the husband acting as [butler]228-butler

and [the wife]229-the wife as [housekeeper]230-housekeeper]226-a mar- ried couple named barrymore , the husband acting as butler and the wife as housekeeper . [Their]226-a mar- ried couple named barrymore , the husband acting as butler and the wife as housekeeper evidence , corroborated

by that of [several friends]231-several friends , tends to show that [Sir Charles]100-sir charles 's

health has for some time been impaired , and points espe-

cially to some affection of the heart , manifesting itself in

changes of colour , breathlessness , and acute attacks of ner-

vous depression . [Dr. James Mortimer]94-dr. mortimer , [the friend]232-the friend and [medi-

cal attendant of [the deceased]234-the deceased]233-medi- cal attendant of the deceased , has given evidence to the

same effect .

" The facts of the case are simple . [Sir Charles Baskerville]100-sir charles[94-dr. mortimer]

was in the habit every night before going to bed of walking

down [the famous yew alley of [Baskerville Hall]115-sir henry]235-the famous yew alley of baskerville hall . The evi-

dence of [the Barrymores]112-the barrymores shows that this had been [his]100-sir charles

custom . On the fourth of May [Sir Charles]100-sir charles had declared [his]100-sir charles

intention of starting next day for [London]2-london , and had ordered

[Barrymore]111-barrymore to prepare [his]100-sir charles luggage . That night [he]100-sir charles went out as

usual for [his]100-sir charles nocturnal walk , in the course of which [he]100-sir charles was

in the habit of smoking a cigar . [He]100-sir charles never returned . At

twelve o'clock [Barrymore]111-barrymore , finding [the hall]1521-the hall door still open ,

became alarmed , and , lighting a lantern , went in search of

[[his]111-barrymore master]1447-his master . The day had been wet , and [Sir Charles]100-sir charles 's foot-

marks were easily traced down [the alley]238-the alley . Halfway down [this

walk]239-this walk there is a gate which leads out on to [the moor]1528-the moor . There

were indications that [Sir Charles]100-sir charles had stood for some little

time [here]1456-here . [He]100-sir charles then proceeded down [the alley]238-the alley , and it was at

the far end of [it]238-the alley that [his]100-sir charles body was discovered . One fact

which has not been explained is the statement of [Barrymore]111-barrymore

that [[his]111-barrymore master]1447-his master 's footprints altered their character from the

time that [he]100-sir charles passed the moor - gate , and that [he]100-sir charles appeared

from thence onward to have been walking upon [his]100-sir charles toes .

One [Murphy]113-murphy , [a gipsy horse - dealer]244-a gipsy horse - dealer , was on [the moor]1528-the moor at no

great distance at the time , but [he]113-murphy appears by [his]113-murphy own

confession to have been the worse for drink . [He]113-murphy declares

that [he]113-murphy heard cries but is unable to state from what direction

[they]246-they came . No signs of violence were to be discovered upon

[[Sir Charles]100-sir charles 's person]247-sir charles 's person , and though [the doctor]248-the doctor 's evidence pointed

to an almost incredible facial distortion - so great that [Dr.

Mortimer]94-dr. mortimer refused at first to believe that it was indeed [[his]94-dr. mortimer

friend]249-his friend and patient who lay before [him]94-dr. mortimer - it was explained

that that is a symptom which is not unusual in cases of

dyspnoea and death from cardiac exhaustion . This expla-

nation was borne out by the post - mortem examination , which

showed long - standing organic disease , and [the coroner 's

jury]250-the coroner 's jury returned a verdict in accordance with the medical evi-

dence . It is well that this is so , for it is obviously of the

utmost importance that [[Sir Charles]100-sir charles 's heir]251-sir charles 's heir should settle at [the

Hall]1521-the hall and continue the good work which has been so sadly

interrupted . Had the prosaic finding of [the coroner]253-the coroner not

finally put an end to the romantic stories which have been

whispered in connection with the affair , it might have been

difficult to find [a tenant for [Baskerville Hall]115-sir henry]254-a tenant for baskerville hall . It is under-

stood that [the next of kin]255-the next of kin is [Mr. Henry Baskerville]114-mr. henry baskerville , if [he]255-the next of kin be

still alive , [the son of [[Sir Charles Baskerville]100-sir charles 's younger

brother]257-sir charles baskerville 's younger brother]256-the son of sir charles baskerville 's younger brother . [The young man]258-the young man when last heard of was in [America]15-america ,

and inquiries are being instituted with a view to informing

[him]258-the young man of [his]258-the young man good fortune . "[94-dr. mortimer]

[Dr. Mortimer]94-dr. mortimer refolded [his]94-dr. mortimer paper and replaced it in [his]94-dr. mortimer pocket .

" Those are the public facts , [Mr. Holmes]96-holmes , in connection with the death of [Sir Charles Baskerville]100-sir charles . "[94-dr. mortimer]

" [I]96-holmes must thank [you]96-holmes , "[96-holmes] said [Sherlock Holmes]96-holmes , " for calling [my]96-holmes attention to a case which certainly presents some features of interest . " It does . "[94-dr. mortimer]

" Then let [me]94-dr. mortimer have the private ones . "[94-dr. mortimer] [He]94-dr. mortimer leaned back , put [his]94-dr. mortimer finger - tips together , and assumed [his]94-dr. mortimer most impassive and judicial expression .

" In doing so , "[94-dr. mortimer] said [Dr. Mortimer]94-dr. mortimer , who had begun to show signs of some strong emotion , " [I]94-dr. mortimer am telling that which [I]94-dr. mortimer have not confided to [anyone]1593-anyone . [My]94-dr. mortimer motive for withholding it from [the coroner]253-the coroner 's inquiry is that [a man of science]1595-a man of science shrinks from placing [himself]1595-a man of science in the public position of seeming to indorse a popular superstition . [I]94-dr. mortimer had the further motive that [Baskerville Hall]115-sir henry , as the paper says , would certainly remain untenanted if anything were done to increase [its]115-sir henry already rather grim reputation . For both these reasons [I]94-dr. mortimer thought that [I]94-dr. mortimer was justified in telling rather less than [I]94-dr. mortimer knew , since no practical good could result from it , but with [you]96-holmes there is no reason why [I]94-dr. mortimer should not be perfectly frank .[94-dr. mortimer]

" [The moor]1528-the moor is very sparsely inhabited , and those who live near [each other]1597-each other are thrown very much together . For this reason [I]94-dr. mortimer saw a good deal of [Sir Charles Baskerville]100-sir charles . With the exception of [Mr. Frankland]116-frankland , of [Lafter Hall]16-lafter hall , and [Mr. Stapleton]117-stapleton , [the naturalist]1598-the naturalist , there are [no other men of education within many miles]1599-no other men of education within many miles . [Sir Charles]100-sir charles was [a retiring man]1600-a retiring man , but the chance of [his]100-sir charles illness brought [us]1601-us together , and a community of interests in science kept [us]1601-us so . [He]100-sir charles had brought back much scientific information from [South Africa]17-south africa , and many a charming evening [we]1601-us have spent together discussing the comparative anatomy of [the Bushman]118-the bushman and [the Hottentot]119-the hottentot .[94-dr. mortimer]

" Within the last few months it became increasingly plain to [me]94-dr. mortimer that [Sir Charles]100-sir charles 's nervous system was strained to the break- ing point . [He]100-sir charles had taken this legend which [I]94-dr. mortimer have read [you]1602-you exceedingly to heart - so much so that , although [he]100-sir charles would walk in [[his]100-sir charles own grounds]1603-his own grounds , nothing would induce [him]100-sir charles to go out upon [the moor]1528-the moor at night . The idea of some ghastly presence constantly haunted [him]100-sir charles , and on more than one occasion [he]100-sir charles has asked [me]94-dr. mortimer whether [I]94-dr. mortimer had on [my]94-dr. mortimer medical journeys at night ever seen [any strange creature]1607-any strange creature or heard the baying of a hound . The latter question [he]100-sir charles put to [me]94-dr. mortimer several times , and always with a voice which vibrated with excitement .[94-dr. mortimer]

" [I]94-dr. mortimer can well remember driving up to [[his]100-sir charles house]1608-his house in the evening some three weeks before the fatal event . [He]100-sir charles chanced to be at [[his]100-sir charles hall]1609-his hall door . [I]94-dr. mortimer had descended from [[my]94-dr. mortimer gig]1610-my gig and was standing in front of [him]100-sir charles , when [I]94-dr. mortimer saw [his]100-sir charles eyes fix themselves over [my]94-dr. mortimer shoulder and stare past [me]94-dr. mortimer with an expression of the most dreadful horror . [I]94-dr. mortimer whisked round and had just time to catch a glimpse of something which [I]94-dr. mortimer took to be [a large black calf passing at the head of the drive]1611-a large black calf passing at the head of the drive . So excited and alarmed was [he]100-sir charles that [I]94-dr. mortimer was compelled to go down to the spot where the animal had been and look around for it . It was gone , however , and the incident appeared to make the worst impression upon [his]100-sir charles mind . [I]94-dr. mortimer stayed with [him]100-sir charles all the evening , and it was on that occasion , to explain the emotion which [he]100-sir charles had shown , that [he]100-sir charles confided to [my]94-dr. mortimer keeping that narrative which [I]94-dr. mortimer read to [you]1612-you when first [I]94-dr. mortimer came . [I]94-dr. mortimer mention this small episode because it assumes some importance in view of the tragedy which followed , but [I]94-dr. mortimer was convinced at the time that the matter was entirely trivial and that [his]100-sir charles excite- ment had no justification .[94-dr. mortimer]

" It was at [my]94-dr. mortimer advice that [Sir Charles]100-sir charles was about to go to [London]2-london . [His]100-sir charles heart was , [I]94-dr. mortimer knew , affected , and the constant anxi- ety in which [he]100-sir charles lived , however chimerical the cause of it might be , was evidently having a serious effect upon [his]100-sir charles health . [I]94-dr. mortimer thought that a few months among the distractions of [town]1420-town would send [him]100-sir charles back [a new man]1614-a new man . " On the night of [Sir Charles]100-sir charles 's death [Barrymore]111-barrymore [the butler who made the discovery]1616-the butler who made the discovery , sent [Perkins the groom on horseback]1617-perkins the groom on horseback to [me]94-dr. mortimer , and as [I]94-dr. mortimer was sitting up late [I]94-dr. mortimer was able to reach [Baskerville Hall]115-sir henry within an hour of the event . " Footprints ? "[94-dr. mortimer]

It would be as well if [you]1406-my dear fellow could make it convenient not to return before evening . Then [I]96-holmes should be very glad to compare impressions as to this most interesting problem which has been submined to [us]1702-us this morning . "[96-holmes]

[I]0-i knew that seclusion and solitude were very necessary for [[my]0-i friend]1476-my friend in those hours of intense mental concentration during which [he]1476-my friend weighed every particle of evidence , constructed alter- native theories , balanced one against the other , and made up [his]1476-my friend mind as to which points were essential and which immaterial . [I]0-i therefore spent the day at [[my]0-i club]266-my club and did not return to [Baker Street]24-baker street until evening . It was nearly nine o'clock when [I]0-i found [myself]0-i in [the sitting - room]267-the sitting - room once more .

[My]0-i first impression as [I]0-i opened the door was that a fire had broken out , for [the room]201-the room was so filled with smoke that the light of the lamp upon the table was blurred by it . As [I]0-i entered , however , [my]0-i fears were set at rest , for it was the acrid fumes of strong coarse tobacco which took [me]0-i by the throat and set [me]0-i coughing . Chapter 4

[Sir Henry Baskerville]115-sir henry

[Our]270-we breakfast table was cleared early , and [Holmes]96-holmes waited in [his]96-holmes dressing - gown for the promised interview . " Most certainly . "[94-dr. mortimer]

" But this is [my]94-dr. mortimer special hobby , and the differences are equally obvious . There is as much difference to [my]94-dr. mortimer eyes between the leaded bourgeois type of a Times article and the slovenly print of an evening half - penny paper as there could be between [[your]96-holmes negro]1767-your negro and [your]96-holmes Esquimau . " Gum , "[96-holmes] said [Holmes]96-holmes .

" With gum on to the paper . But [I]94-dr. mortimer want to know why the word ' moor ' should have been written ? "[94-dr. mortimer]

" Why , of course , that would explain it . Have [you]115-sir henry read any- thing else in this message , [Mr. Holmes]96-holmes ? "[94-dr. mortimer]

" There are one or two indications , and yet the utmost pains have been taken to remove all clues . The address , [you]96-holmes observe is printed in rough characters . But the Times is a paper which is seldom found in any hands but those of the highly educated . [We]1770-we may take it , therefore , that the letter was composed by [an educated man who wished to pose as [an uneducated one]1773-an uneducated one]1772-an educated man who wished to pose as an uneducated one , and [his]1772-an educated man who wished to pose as an uneducated one effort to conceal [his]1772-an educated man who wished to pose as an uneducated one own writing suggests that that writing might be known , or come to be known , by [you]96-holmes . Again , [you]96-holmes will observe that the words are not gummed on in an accurate line , but that some are much higher than others . ' Life , ' for example is quite out of its proper place . That may point to carelessness or it may point to agitation and hurry upon the part of [the cutter]1774-the cutter . On the whole [I]94-dr. mortimer incline to the latter view , since the matter was evidently important , and it is unlikely that [the composer of such a letter]1775-the composer of such a letter would be careless . If [he]1775-the composer of such a letter were in a hurry it opens up the interesting question why [he]1775-the composer of such a letter should be in a hurry , since any letter posted up to early morning would reach [Sir Henry]115-sir henry before [he]1775-the composer of such a letter would leave [[his]1775-the composer of such a letter hotel]1776-his hotel . " [We]1770-we are coming now rather into the region of guesswork , "[94-dr. mortimer] said [Dr. Mortimer]94-dr. mortimer .

" Say , rather , into the region where [we]1770-we balance probabilities and choose the most likely . " How in [the world]1458-the world can [you]94-dr. mortimer say that ? "[94-dr. mortimer]

" If [you]96-holmes examine it carefully [you]96-holmes will see that both the pen and the ink have given [the writer]1780-the writer trouble . Now , a private pen or ink - bottle is seldom allowed to be in such a state , and the combination of the two must be quite rare . But [you]96-holmes know [the hotel]1781-the hotel ink and the hotel pen , where it is rare to get anything else . " Well ? "[94-dr. mortimer]

"[289-i]

" Why , no , [Mr. Holmes]96-holmes . [I]94-dr. mortimer think not . "[94-dr. mortimer]

" [You]115-sir henry have not observed [anyone]1593-anyone follow or watch [you]115-sir henry ? "[289-i]

" [We]1770-we are coming to that . [You]115-sir henry have nothing else to report to [us]1770-we before [we]1770-we go into this matter ? "[289-i]

" Well , it depends upon what [you]115-sir henry think worth reporting . "[94-dr. mortimer]

" [I]289-i think anything out of the ordinary routine of life well worth reporting . "[289-i]

[Sir Henry]115-sir henry smiled .

" [I]289-i do n't know much of [British]32-british life yet , for [I]289-i have spent nearly all [my]289-i time in [the States]1786-the states and in [Canada]19-canada . But [I]289-i hope that to lose one of [your]115-sir henry boots is not part of the ordinary routine of life over here . "[289-i]

" [You]115-sir henry have lost one of [your]115-sir henry boots ? "[289-i]

" [[My]94-dr. mortimer dear [sir]1459-sir]1787-my dear sir , "[94-dr. mortimer] cried [Dr. Mortimer]94-dr. mortimer , " it is only mislaid . " Well , [he]96-holmes asked [me]289-i for anything outside the ordinary routine . "[289-i]

" Well , mislaid it , anyhow . [I]289-i put them both outside [my]289-i door last night , and there was only one in the morning . Chapter 5

[Three Broken Threads

Sherlock Holmes]127-holmes had , in a very remarkable degree , the power of detaching [his]323-he mind at will . For two hours the strange business in which [we]324-we had been involved appeared to be forgotten , and [he]323-he was entirely absorbed in the pictures of [the modern Belgian masters]325-the modern belgian masters . " [Sir Henry Baskerville]115-sir henry is [upstairs]1869-upstairs expecting [you]328-the clerk , "[328-the clerk] said [the clerk]328-the clerk . " [He]115-sir henry asked [me]328-the clerk to show [you]328-the clerk up at once when [you]328-the clerk came . "[328-the clerk]

" What does it suggest ? "[115-sir henry]

As [we]335-we came round the top of the stairs [we]335-we had run up against [Sir Henry Baskerville]115-sir henry [himself]115-sir henry . " Seems to [me]115-sir henry [they]1887-the people who are so interested in our friend have not settled down in his own hotel are playing [me]115-sir henry for a sucker in [this hotel]1755-this hotel , "[115-sir henry] [he]115-sir henry cried . " [They]1887-the people who are so interested in our friend have not settled down in his own hotel 'll find [they]1887-the people who are so interested in our friend have not settled down in his own hotel 've stafted in to monkey with [the wrong man]1892-the wrong man unless [they]1887-the people who are so interested in our friend have not settled down in his own hotel are careful . Then [he]2001-my gentleman paid up [his]2001-my gentleman two guineas , like a good one , and away [he]2001-my gentleman went into [the station]2003-the station . Only just as [he]2001-my gentleman was leaving [he]2001-my gentleman turned round and [he]2001-my gentleman said : ' It might interest [you]1833-the cabman to know that [you]1833-the cabman have been driving [Mr. Sherlock Holmes]96-holmes . ' That 's how [I]1833-the cabman come to know the name . "[1833-the cabman]

" [I]1833-the cabman see . And [you]1833-the cabman saw no more of [him]96-holmes ? "[1833-the cabman]

" Not after [he]96-holmes went into [the station]2003-the station . "[1833-the cabman]

" And how would [you]1833-the cabman describe [Mr. Sherlock Holmes]96-holmes ? "[1833-the cabman]

Chapter 6

[Baskerville Hall

Sir Henry Baskerville]115-sir henry and [Dr. Mortimer]94-dr. mortimer were ready upon the appointed day , and [we]358-we started as arranged for [Devonshire]10-devonshire . " [I]96-holmes will not bias [your]0-i mind by suggesting theories or suspi- cions , [Watson]95-watson , "[96-holmes] said [he]96-holmes ; " [I]96-holmes wish [you]0-i simply to report facts in the fullest possible manner to [me]96-holmes , and [you]0-i can leave [me]96-holmes to do the theorizing . In a very few hours the brown earth had become ruddy , the brick had changed to granite , and red cows grazed in well - hedged fields where the lush grasses and more luxuriant vegetation spoke of a richer , if a damper , climate . [The train]365-the train pulled up at [a small wayside station]384-a small wayside station and [we]381-we all descended . [The wagonette]398-the wagonette swung round into [a side road]399-a side road , and [we]381-we curved upward through deep lanes worn by centuries of wheels , high banks on either side , heavy with dripping moss and fleshy hart's - tongue ferns . " [Halloa]123-halloa ! "[94-dr. mortimer] cried [Dr. Mortimer]94-dr. mortimer , " what is this ? "[94-dr. mortimer]

[I]0-i remembered the case well , for it was one in which [Holmes]96-holmes had taken an interest on account of the peculiar ferocity of the crime and the wanton brutality which had marked all the actions of [the assassin]412-the assassin . " Welcome , [Sir Henry]115-sir henry ! Welcome to [Baskerville Hall]115-sir henry ! "[445-a tall man]

"[94-dr. mortimer]

The wheels died away down [the drive]451-the drive while [Sir Henry]115-sir henry and [I]0-i turned into [the hall]1521-the hall , and the door clanged heavily behind [us]453-our . [I]0-i drew aside [my]0-i curtains before [I]0-i went to bed and looked out from [my]0-i window . Beyond , two copses of trees moaned and swung in a rising wind . A half moon broke through the rifts of racing clouds . In its cold light [I]0-i saw beyond the trees a broken fringe of rocks , and the long , low curve of [the melancholy moor]489-the melancholy moor . [I]0-i closed the curtain , feeling that [my]0-i last impression was in keeping with the rest .

And yet it was not quite the last . [I]0-i found [myself]0-i weary and yet wakeful , tossing restlessly from side to side , seeking for the sleep which would not come . Far away a chiming clock struck out the quarters of the hours , but otherwise a deathly silence lay upon [the old house]490-the old house . And then suddenly , in the very dead of the night , there came a sound to [my]0-i ears , clear , resonant , and unmistakable . It was the sob of [a woman]1620-a woman , the muffled , strangling gasp of [one who is torn by an uncontrollable sorrow]492-one who is torn by an uncontrollable sorrow . [I]0-i sat up in bed and listened intently . The noise could not have been far away and was certainly in [the house]1540-the house . For half an hour [I]0-i waited with every nerve on the alert , but there came no other sound save the chiming clock and the rustle of the ivy on the wall .

Chapter 7

[The Stapletons of [Merripit House]52-merripit house]494-the stapletons of merripit house

The fresh beauty of the following morning did something to efface from [our]495-our minds the grim and gray impression which had been left upon both of [us]495-our by [our]495-our first experience of [Baskerville Hall]115-sir henry . As [Sir Henry]115-sir henry and [I]0-i sat at breakfast the sunlight flooded in through the high mullioned windows , throwing watery patches of colour from the coats of arms which covered them . The dark panelling glowed like bronze in the golden rays , and it was hard to realize that this was indeed the chamber which had struck such a gloom into [our]495-our souls upon the evening before .

" [I]292-the baronet guess it is [ourselves]495-our and not [the house]1540-the house that [we]495-our have to blame ! "[292-the baronet] said [the baronet]292-the baronet . " And yet it was not entirely a question of imagination , "[0-i] [I]0-i answered . " Did [you]0-i , for example , happen to hear [someone]1746-someone , [a woman]1620-a woman [I]0-i think , sobbing in the night ? "[0-i]

" That is curious , for [I]292-the baronet did when [I]292-the baronet was half asleep fancy that [I]292-the baronet heard something of the sort . [I]292-the baronet waited quite a time , but there was no more of it , so [I]292-the baronet concluded that it was all a dream . "[292-the baronet]

" [I]497-he heard it distinctly , and [I]497-he am sure that it was really the sob of [a woman]1620-a woman . "[497-he]

And yet [he]497-he lied as [he]497-he said it , for it chanced that after breakfast [I]0-i met [Mrs. Barrymore]143-barrymore in [the long corridor]501-the long corridor with the sun full upon [her]143-barrymore face . But [her]143-barrymore telltale eyes were red and glanced at [me]0-i from between swollen lids . Yet [he]1883-her husband had taken the obvious risk of discovery in declaring that it was not so . Why had [he]1883-her husband done this ? And why did [she]143-barrymore weep so bitterly ? "[117-stapleton]

[We]538-us had come to a point where [a narrow grassy path]539-a narrow grassy path struck off from [the road]423-the road and wound away across [the moor]1528-the moor . [We]2235-we knew [him]100-sir charles very intimately , for [his]100-sir charles favourite walk was over [the moor]1528-the moor to [[our]2235-we house]2237-our house . [He]100-sir charles was deeply impressed with the curse which hung over [the family]1582-the family , and when this tragedy came [I]604-i naturally felt that there must be some grounds for the fears which [he]100-sir charles had expressed . [I]604-i was distressed therefore when [another member of [the family]1582-the family]2239-another member of the family came down to live [here]1456-here , and [I]604-i felt that [he]2239-another member of the family should be warned of the danger which [he]2239-another member of the family will run . That was all which [I]604-i intended to convey .[604-i]

" But what is the danger ? "[147-stapleton]

" [You]604-i know the story of the hound ? "[604-i]

" [I]147-stapleton do not believe in such nonsense . "[147-stapleton]

" But [I]604-i do . If [you]604-i have any influence with [Sir Henry]115-sir henry , take [him]115-sir henry away from a place which has always been fatal to [[his]115-sir henry family]1605-his family . [The world]1458-the world is wide . Why should [he]115-sir henry wish to live at [the place of danger]2244-the place of danger ? "[604-i]

" Because [it]2244-the place of danger is [the place of danger]2244-the place of danger . That is [Sir Henry]115-sir henry 's nature . [I]147-stapleton fear that unless [you]604-i can give [me]147-stapleton some more definite informa- tion than this it would be impossible to get [him]115-sir henry to move . "[147-stapleton]

" [I]604-i can not say anything definite , for [I]604-i do not know anything definite . "[604-i]

" [I]147-stapleton would ask [you]604-i one more question , [Miss Stapleton]147-stapleton . If [you]604-i meant no more than this when [you]604-i first spoke to [me]147-stapleton , why should [you]604-i not wish [[your]604-i brother]2246-your brother to overhear what [you]604-i said ? There is nothing to which [he]2246-your brother , or [anyone else]1935-anyone else , could object . "[147-stapleton]

" [[My]605-i brother]2200-my brother is very anxious to have [the Hall]1521-the hall inhabited , for [he]2200-my brother thinks it is for the good of [the poor folk upon [the moor]1528-the moor]2250-the poor folk upon the moor . [He]2200-my brother would be very angry if [he]2200-my brother knew that [I]605-i have said anything which might induce [Sir Henry]115-sir henry to go away . But [I]605-i have done [my]605-i duty now and [I]605-i will say no more . [I]605-i must go back , or [he]2200-my brother will miss [me]605-i and suspect that [I]605-i have seen [you]605-i . Good - bye ! "[605-i] [She]605-i turned and had disappeared in a few minutes among the scattered boulders , while [I]0-i , with [my]0-i soul full of vague fears , pursued [my]0-i way to [Baskerville Hall]115-sir henry .

Chapter 8

First Report of [Dr. Watson]95-watson

From this point onward [I]0-i will follow the course of events by transcribing [my]0-i own letters to [Mr. Sherlock Holmes]96-holmes which lie before [me]0-i on the table . One page is missing , but otherwise they are exactly as written and show [my]0-i feelings and suspicions of the moment more accurately than [my]0-i memory , clear as it is upon these tragic events , can possibly do .

[Baskerville Hall]115-sir henry , October 13th .

[[My]0-i dear]1408-my dear [Holmes]96-holmes :

[My]0-i previous letters and telegrams have kept [you]96-holmes pretty well up to date as to all that has occurred in [this most God - forsaken corner of [the world]1458-the world]607-this most god - forsaken corner of the world . The longer one stays here the more does the spirit of [the moor]1528-the moor sink into [one]1629-one 's soul , its vastness , and also its grim charm . When [you]96-holmes are once out upon [its]1528-the moor bosom [you]96-holmes have left all traces of modern [England]14-england behind [you]96-holmes , but , on the other hand , [you]96-holmes are conscious everywhere of [the homes]611-the homes and the work of [the prehistoric people]612-the prehistoric people . On all sides of [you]96-holmes as [you]96-holmes walk are [the houses of [these forgotten folk]614-these forgotten folk]613-the houses of these forgotten folk , with [their]614-these forgotten folk graves and the huge monoliths which are supposed to have marked [[their]614-these forgotten folk temples]615-their temples . As [you]96-holmes look at [[their]614-these forgotten folk gray stone huts against the scarred hillsides]616-their gray stone huts against the scarred hillsides [you]96-holmes leave [your]96-holmes own age behind [you]96-holmes , and if [you]96-holmes were to see [a skin - clad , hairy man]617-a skin - clad , hairy man crawl out from the low door fitting a flint - tipped arrow on to the string of [his]617-a skin - clad , hairy man bow , [you]96-holmes wouid feel that [his]617-a skin - clad , hairy man presence there was more natural than [your]96-holmes own . The strange thing is that [they]614-these forgotten folk should have lived so thickly on what must always have been most unfruitful soil . [I]0-i am [no antiquarian]618-no antiquarian , but [I]0-i could imagine that [they]614-these forgotten folk were [some unwarlike and harried race who were forced to accept that which [none other]620-none other would occupy]619-some unwarlike and harried race who were forced to accept that which none other would occupy .

All this , however , is foreign to the mission on which [you]96-holmes sent [me]0-i and will probably be very uninteresting to [your]96-holmes severely practical mind . [I]0-i can still remember [your]96-holmes complete indifference as to whether the sun moved round [the earth]621-the earth or [the earth]621-the earth round the sun . Let [me]0-i , therefore , return to the facts concerning [Sir Henry Baskerville]115-sir henry .

If [you]96-holmes have not had any report within the last few days it is because up to to - day there was nothing of importance to relate . Then a very surprising circumstance occurred , which [I]0-i shall tell [you]96-holmes in due course . But , first of all , [I]0-i must keep [you]96-holmes in touch with some of the other factors in the situation .

One of these , concerning which [I]0-i have said little , is [the escaped convict upon [the moor]1528-the moor]623-the escaped convict upon the moor . There is strong reason now to believe that [he]623-the escaped convict upon the moor has got right away , which is a considerable relief to [the lonely householders of [this district]626-this district]625-the lonely householders of this district . A fortnight has passed since [his]623-the escaped convict upon the moor flight , during which [he]623-the escaped convict upon the moor has not been seen and nothing has been heard of [him]623-the escaped convict upon the moor . It is surely inconceivable that [he]623-the escaped convict upon the moor could have held out upon [the moor]1528-the moor during all that time . Of course , so far as [his]623-the escaped convict upon the moor concealment goes there is no difficulty at all . [Any one of [these stone huts]629-these stone huts]628-any one of these stone huts would give [him]623-the escaped convict upon the moor a hiding - place . But there is nothing to eat unless [he]623-the escaped convict upon the moor were to catch and slaughter one of the moor sheep . [We]630-we think , therefore , that [he]623-the escaped convict upon the moor has gone , and [the outlying farmers]631-the outlying farmers sleep the better in consequence .

[We]630-we are [four able - bodied men in [this household]633-this household]632-four able - bodied men in this household , so that [we]630-we could take good care of [ourselves]630-we , but [I]0-i confess that [I]0-i have had uneasy moments when [I]0-i have thought of [the Stapletons]151-the stapletons . [They]151-the stapletons live miles from any help . There are [one maid]634-one maid , [an old manser- vant]635-an old manser- vant , [the sister]636-the sister , and [the brother]637-the brother , [the latter]210-the latter not [a very strong man]639-a very strong man . [They]151-the stapletons would be helpless in the hands of [a desperate fellow like this Notting Hill criminal]640-a desperate fellow like this notting hill criminal if [he]640-a desperate fellow like this notting hill criminal could once effect an entrance . Both [Sir Henry]115-sir henry and [I]0-i were concerned at [their]151-the stapletons situation , and it was suggested that [Perkins]139-perkins [the groom]641-the groom should go over to sleep there , but [Stapleton]147-stapleton would not hear of it .

The fact is that [[our]642-our friend]1718-our friend , [the baronet]292-the baronet , begins to display a considerable interest in [[our]642-our fair neighbour]645-our fair neighbour . It is not to be won- dered at , for time hangs heavily in this lonely spot to [an active man like [him]292-the baronet]646-an active man like him , and [she]645-our fair neighbour is [a very fascinating and beautiful woman]647-a very fascinating and beautiful woman . There is something tropical and exotic about [her]645-our fair neighbour which forms a singular contrast to [[her]645-our fair neighbour cool and unemotional brother]648-her cool and unemotional brother . Yet [he]292-the baronet also gives the idea of hidden fires . [He]292-the baronet has certainly a very marked influence over [her]645-our fair neighbour , for [I]0-i have seen [her]645-our fair neighbour continually glance at [him]292-the baronet as [she]645-our fair neighbour talked as if seeking approbation for what [she]645-our fair neighbour said . [I]0-i trust that [he]292-the baronet is kind to [her]645-our fair neighbour . There is a dry glitter in [his]292-the baronet eyes and a firm set of [his]292-the baronet thin lips , which goes with a positive and possibly a harsh nature . [You]649-you would find [him]292-the baronet an interesting study .

[He]292-the baronet came over to call upon [Baskerville]20-baskerville on that first day , and the very next morning [he]292-the baronet took [us]650-us both to show [us]650-us the spot where the legend of [the wicked Hugo]651-the wicked hugo is supposed to have had its origin . It was an excursion of some miles across [the moor]1528-the moor to a place which is so dismal that it might have suggested the story . [We]650-us found [a short valley between [rugged tors]654-rugged tors]653-a short valley between rugged tors which led to [an open , grassy space flecked over with the white cotton grass]655-an open , grassy space flecked over with the white cotton grass . In the middle of [it]653-a short valley between rugged tors rose two great stones , worn and sharpened at the upper end until they looked like the huge corroding fangs of some monstrous beast . In every way it corresponded with the scene of the old tragedy . [Sir Henry]115-sir henry was much interested and asked [Stapleton]147-stapleton more than once whether [he]292-the baronet did really believe in the possibility of the interference of the supernatural in the affairs of [men]1729-men . [He]292-the baronet spoke lightly , but it was evident that [he]292-the baronet was very much in earnest . [Stapleton]147-stapleton was guarded in [his]292-the baronet replies , but it was easy to see that [he]292-the baronet said less than [he]292-the baronet might , and that [he]292-the baronet would not express [his]292-the baronet whole opinion out of consideration for the feelings of [the baronet]292-the baronet . [He]292-the baronet told [us]650-us of similar cases , where [families]658-families had suffered from some evil influence , and [he]292-the baronet left [us]650-us with the impression that [he]292-the baronet shared the popular view upon the matter .

On [our]650-us way back [we]650-us stayed for lunch at [Merripit House]52-merripit house , and it was there that [Sir Henry]115-sir henry made the acquaintance of [Miss Stapleton]147-stapleton . From the first moment that [he]292-the baronet saw [her]147-stapleton [he]292-the baronet appeared to be strongly attracted by [her]147-stapleton , and [I]0-i am much mistaken if the feeling was not mutual . [He]292-the baronet referred to [her]147-stapleton again and again on [our]650-us walk [home]1520-home , and since then hardly a day has passed that [we]650-us have not seen something of [the brother and sister]660-the brother and sister . [They]660-the brother and sister dine here to - night , and there is some talk of [our]650-us going to [them]660-the brother and sister next week . One would imagine that such a match would be very welcome to [Stapleton]147-stapleton , and yet [I]0-i have more than once caught a look of the strongest disapprobation in [his]292-the baronet face when [Sir Henry]115-sir henry has been paying some attention to [[his]115-sir henry sister]2032-his sister . [He]292-the baronet is much attached to [her]2032-his sister , no doubt , and would lead a lonely life without [her]2032-his sister , but it would seem the height of selfishness if [he]292-the baronet were to stand in the way of [her]2032-his sister making so brilliant a marriage . Yet [I]0-i am certain that [he]292-the baronet does not wish [their]660-the brother and sister intimacy to ripen into love , and [I]0-i have several times observed that [he]292-the baronet has taken pains to prevent [them]660-the brother and sister from being tete - a - tete . By the way , [your]662-your instructions to [me]0-i never to allow [Sir Henry]115-sir henry to go out alone will become very much more onerous if a love affair were to be added to [our]663-us other difficulties . [My]0-i popularity would soon suffer if [I]0-i were to carry out [your]662-your orders to the letter .

The other day - Thursday , to be more exact - [Dr. Mortimer]94-dr. mortimer lunched with [us]663-us . [He]94-dr. mortimer has been excavating [a barrow at [Long Down]56-long down]664-a barrow at long down and has got a prehistoric skull which fills [him]94-dr. mortimer with great joy . Never was there such [a single - minded enthusiast as [he]94-dr. mortimer]665-a single - minded enthusiast as he ! [The Stapletons]151-the stapletons came in afterwards , and [the good doctor]666-the good doctor took [us]663-us all to [the yew alley]1618-the yew alley at [Sir Henry]115-sir henry 's request to show [us]663-us exactly how everything occurred upon that fatal night . It is a long , dismal walk , [the yew alley]1618-the yew alley , between two high walls of clipped hedge , with a narrow band of grass upon either side . At the far end is [an old tumble - down summer - house]669-an old tumble - down summer - house . Halfway down is the moor- gate , where [the old gentleman]670-the old gentleman left [his]670-the old gentleman cigar - ash . It is a white wooden gate with a latch . Beyond it lies [the wide moor]671-the wide moor . [I]0-i remembered [your]672-your theory of the affair and tried to picture all that had occurred . As [the old man]506-the old man stood there [he]506-the old man saw something coming across [the moor]1528-the moor , something which terrified [him]506-the old man so that [he]506-the old man lost [his]506-the old man wits and ran and ran until [he]506-the old man died of sheer horror and exhaustion . There was [the long , gloomy tunnel down which [he]506-the old man fled]675-the long , gloomy tunnel down which he fled . And from what ? A sheep - dog of [the moor]1528-the moor ? Or a spectral hound , black , silent , and monstrous ? Was there a human agency in the matter ? Did [the pale , watchful Barrymore]111-barrymore know more than [he]111-barrymore cared to say ? It was all dim and vague , but always there is the dark shadow of crime behind it .

[One other neighbour [I]0-i have met]677-one other neighbour i have met since [I]0-i wrote last . This is [Mr. Frankland]116-frankland , of [Lafter Hall]16-lafter hall , who lives some four miles to [the south of [us]679-us]678-the south of us . [He]116-frankland is [an elderly man , red - faced , white - haired]680-an elderly man , red - faced , white - haired , and cho- leric . [His]116-frankland passion is for the British law , and [he]116-frankland has spent a large fortune in litigation . [He]116-frankland fights for the mere pleasure of fighting and is equally ready to take up either side of a question , so that it is no wonder that [he]116-frankland has found it a costly amusement . Some- times [he]116-frankland will shut up a right of way and defy [the parish]681-the parish to make [him]116-frankland open [it]682-it . At others [he]116-frankland will with [his]116-frankland own hands tear down [some other man]683-some other man 's gate and declare that a path has existed there from time immemorial , defying [the owner]1953-the owner to prosecute [him]116-frankland for trespass . [He]116-frankland is learned in old manorial and communal rights , and [he]116-frankland applies [his]116-frankland knowledge sometimes in favour of [the villagers of [Fernworthy]57-fernworthy]685-the villagers of fernworthy and sometimes against [them]685-the villagers of fernworthy , so that [he]116-frankland is periodi- cally either carried in triumph down [the village street]686-the village street or else burned in effigy , according to [his]116-frankland latest exploit . [He]116-frankland is said to have about seven lawsuits upon [his]116-frankland hands at present , which will probably swallow up the remainder of [his]116-frankland fortune and so draw [his]116-frankland sting and leave [him]116-frankland harmless for the future . Apart from the law [he]116-frankland seems [a kindly , good - natured person]687-a kindly , good - natured person , and [I]0-i only mention [him]116-frankland because [you]688-you were particular that [I]0-i should send some descrip- tion of [the people who surround [us]690-us]689-the people who surround us . [He]116-frankland is curiously employed at present , for , being [an amateur astronomer]691-an amateur astronomer , [he]116-frankland has an excellent telescope , with which [he]116-frankland lies upon the roof of [[his]116-frankland own house]1745-his own house and sweeps [the moor]1528-the moor all day in the hope of catching a glimpse of [the escaped convict]694-the escaped convict . If [he]116-frankland would confine [his]116-frankland energies to this all would be well , but there are rumours that [he]116-frankland intends to prosecute [Dr. Mortimer]94-dr. mortimer for opening [a grave]695-a grave without the consent of [the next of kin]255-the next of kin because [he]116-frankland dug up the neolithic skull in [the barrow on [Long Down]58-long down]697-the barrow on long down . [He]116-frankland helps to keep [our]690-us lives from being monotonous and gives a little comic relief where it is badly needed .

And now , having brought [you]698-you up to date in [the escaped convict]694-the escaped convict , [the Stapletons]151-the stapletons , [Dr. Mortimer]94-dr. mortimer , and [Frankland]116-frankland , of [Lafter Hall]16-lafter hall , let [me]0-i end on that which is most important and tell [you]698-you more about [the Barrymores]112-the barrymores , and especially about the surprising development of last night .

First of all about the test telegram , which [you]698-you sent from [London]2-london in order to make sure that [Barrymore]111-barrymore was really [here]1456-here . [I]0-i have already explained that the testimony of [the postmaster]1918-the postmaster shows that the test was worthless and that [we]690-us have no proof one way or the other . [I]0-i told [Sir Henry]115-sir henry how the matter stood , and [he]115-sir henry at once , in [his]115-sir henry downright fashion , had [Barrymore]111-barrymore up and asked [him]115-sir henry whether [he]115-sir henry had received the telegram [himself]115-sir henry . [Barrymore]111-barrymore said that [he]115-sir henry had .

" Did [the boy]2252-the boy deliver it into [your]115-sir henry own hands ? "[115-sir henry] asked [Sir Henry]115-sir henry .

[Barrymore]111-barrymore looked surprised , and considered for a little time .

" No , "[115-sir henry] said [he]115-sir henry , " [I]115-sir henry was in [the box - room]2253-the box - room at the time , and [[my]115-sir henry wife]2076-my wife brought it up to [me]115-sir henry . "[115-sir henry]

" Did [you]115-sir henry answer it [yourself]115-sir henry ? "[115-sir henry]

In the evening [he]115-sir henry recurred to the subject of [his]115-sir henry own accord .

" [I]115-sir henry could not quite understand the object of [your]115-sir henry questions this morning , [Sir Henry]115-sir henry , "[115-sir henry] said [he]115-sir henry . " [I]115-sir henry trust that [they]2256-they do not mean that [I]115-sir henry have done anything to forfeit [your]115-sir henry confidence ? "[115-sir henry]

[Mrs. Barrymore]143-barrymore is of interest to [me]0-i . [She]143-barrymore is [a heavy , solid person , very limited , intensely respectable , and inclined to be puritanical]702-a heavy , solid person , very limited , intensely respectable , and inclined to be puritanical . [You]703-you could hardly conceive a less emotional subject . Yet [I]0-i have told [you]703-you how , on the first night here , [I]0-i heard [her]143-barrymore sobbing bitterly , and since then [I]0-i have more than once observed traces of tears upon [her]143-barrymore face . Some deep sorrow gnaws ever at [her]143-barrymore heart . Sometimes [I]0-i wonder if [she]143-barrymore has a guilty memory which haunts [her]143-barrymore , and sometimes [I]0-i suspect [Barrymore]143-barrymore of being [a domestic tyrant]704-a domestic tyrant . [I]0-i have always felt that there was something singular and questionable in [this man]705-this man 's character , but the adven- ture of last night brings all [my]0-i suspicions to a head .

And yet it may seem a small matter in itself . [You]703-you are aware that [I]0-i am not [a very sound sleeper]706-a very sound sleeper , and since [I]0-i have been on guard in [this house]1981-this house [my]0-i slumbers have been lighter than ever . Last night , about two in the morning , [I]0-i was aroused by a stealthy step passing [[my]0-i room]708-my room . [I]0-i rose , opened [my]0-i door , and peeped out . A long black shadow was trailing down [the corridor]709-the corridor . It was thrown by [a man who walked softly down [the passage]711-the passage with a candle held in [his]710-a man who walked softly down the passage with a candle held in his hand hand]710-a man who walked softly down the passage with a candle held in his hand . [He]710-a man who walked softly down the passage with a candle held in his hand was in shirt and trousers , with no covering to [his]710-a man who walked softly down the passage with a candle held in his hand feet . [I]0-i could merely see the outline , but [his]710-a man who walked softly down the passage with a candle held in his hand height told [me]0-i that it was [Barrymore]143-barrymore . [He]710-a man who walked softly down the passage with a candle held in his hand walked very slowly and circumspectly , and there was something indescribably guilty and furtive in [his]710-a man who walked softly down the passage with a candle held in his hand whole appearance .

[I]0-i have told [you]712-you that [the corridor]709-the corridor is broken by the balcony which runs round [the hall]1521-the hall , but that it is resumed upon the farther side . [I]0-i waited until [he]710-a man who walked softly down the passage with a candle held in his hand had passed out of sight and then [I]0-i followed [him]710-a man who walked softly down the passage with a candle held in his hand . When [I]0-i came round [the balcony]715-the balcony [he]710-a man who walked softly down the passage with a candle held in his hand had reached the end of [the farther corridor]716-the farther corridor , and [I]0-i could see from the glimmer of light through an open door that [he]710-a man who walked softly down the passage with a candle held in his hand had entered [one of [the rooms]718-the rooms]717-one of the rooms . Now , all [these rooms]467-these rooms are unfurnished and unoccupied so that [his]710-a man who walked softly down the passage with a candle held in his hand expedition became more mysterious than ever . The light shone steadily as if [he]710-a man who walked softly down the passage with a candle held in his hand were standing motionless . [I]0-i crept down [the passage]711-the passage as noiselessly as [I]0-i could and peeped round the corner of the door .

[Barrymore]143-barrymore was crouching at the window with the candle held against the glass . [His]710-a man who walked softly down the passage with a candle held in his hand profile was half turned towards [me]0-i , and [his]710-a man who walked softly down the passage with a candle held in his hand face seemed to be rigid with expectation as [he]710-a man who walked softly down the passage with a candle held in his hand stared out into the blackness of [the moor]1528-the moor . For some minutes [he]710-a man who walked softly down the passage with a candle held in his hand stood watching intently . Then [he]710-a man who walked softly down the passage with a candle held in his hand gave a deep groan and with an impatient gesture [he]710-a man who walked softly down the passage with a candle held in his hand put out the light . Instantly [I]0-i made [my]0-i way back to [[my]0-i room]708-my room , and very shortly came the stealthy steps passing once more upon [their]723-their return journey . Long afterwards when [I]0-i had fallen into a light sleep [I]0-i heard a key turn somewhere in a lock , but [I]0-i could not tell whence the sound came . What it all means [I]0-i can not guess , but there is some secret business going on in [this house of gloom]724-this house of gloom which sooner or later [we]725-we shall get to the bottom of . [I]0-i do not trouble [you]726-you with [my]0-i theories , for [you]726-you asked [me]0-i to furnish [you]726-you only with facts . [I]0-i have had a long talk with [Sir Henry]115-sir henry this morning , and [we]725-we have made a plan of campaign founded upon [my]0-i observations of last night . [I]0-i will not speak about it just now , but it should make [my]0-i next report interesting reading .

Chapter 9

Second Report of [Dr. Watson]95-watson

[THE LIGHT UPON THE MOOR

Baskerville Hall]727-the light upon the moor baskerville hall , [Oct. 15th]59-oct. 15th .

[MY]0-i DEAR [HOLMES]96-holmes :

If [I]0-i was compelled to leave [you]726-you without much news during the early days of [my]0-i mission [you]726-you must acknowledge that [I]0-i am making up for lost time , and that events are now crowding thick and fast upon [us]725-we . In [my]0-i last report [I]0-i ended upon [my]0-i top note with [Barrymore]143-barrymore at the window , and now [I]0-i have quite a budget already which will , unless [I]0-i am much mistaken , considera- bly surprise [you]726-you . Things have taken a turn which [I]0-i could not have anticipated . In some ways they have within the last forty- eight hours become much clearer and in some ways they have become more complicated . But [I]0-i will tell [you]726-you all and [you]726-you shall judge for [yourself]726-you .

Before breakfast on the morning following [my]0-i adventure [I]0-i went down [the corridor]709-the corridor and examined [the room in which [Barry-]144-barry- more had been on the - night before]729-the room in which barry- more had been on the - night before . The western window through which [he]144-barry- had stared so intently has , [I]0-i noticed , one peculiarity above all other windows in [the house]1540-the house - it commands the nearest outlook on to [the moor]1528-the moor . There is an opening between two trees which enables one from this point of view to look right down upon [it]732-it , while from all the other windows it is only a distant glimpse which can be obtained . It follows , therefore , that [Barry-]144-barry- more , since only this window would serve the purpose , must have been looking out for something or [somebody upon]733-somebody upon [the moor]1528-the moor . The night was very dark , so that [I]0-i can hardly imagine how [he]144-barry- could have hoped to see [anyone]1593-anyone . It had struck [me]0-i that it was possible that some love intrigue was on foot . That would have accounted for [his]144-barry- stealthy movements and also for the uneasiness of [[his]144-barry- wife]1925-his wife . [The man]1397-the man is [a striking - looking fellow]738-a striking - looking fellow , very well equipped to steal the heart of [a country girl]739-a country girl , so that this theory seemed to have something to support it . That opening of the door whlch [I]0-i had heard after [I]0-i had returned to [[my]0-i room]708-my room might mean that [he]144-barry- had gone out to keep some clandestine appointment . So [I]0-i reasoned with [myself]0-i in the morning , and [I]0-i tell [you]741-you the direction of [my]0-i suspicions , however much the result may have shown that they were unfounded .

But whatever the true explanation of [Barrymore]143-barrymore 's movements might be , [I]0-i felt that the responsibility of keeping them to [myself]0-i until [I]0-i could explain them was more than [I]0-i could bear . [I]0-i had an interview with [the baronet]292-the baronet in [[his]292-the baronet study]743-his study after breakfast , and [I]0-i told [him]292-the baronet all that [I]0-i had seen . [He]292-the baronet was less surprised than [I]0-i had expected .

"[0-i] [Sir Henry]115-sir henry rubbed [his]115-sir henry hands with pleasure , and it was evident that [he]115-sir henry hailed the adventure as a relief to [his]115-sir henry somewhat quiet life upon [the moor]1528-the moor .

[The baronet]292-the baronet has been in communication with [the architect who prepared the plans for [Sir Charles]100-sir charles , and with [a contractor from [London]2-london]747-a contractor from london]746-the architect who prepared the plans for sir charles , and with a contractor from london , so that [we]748-our may expect great changes to begin here soon . Between [ourselves]748-our there are pretty clear signs that this will not be wanting if [the lady]590-the lady is willing , for [I]0-i have seldom seen [a man]1619-a man more infatuated with [a woman]1620-a woman than [he]1619-a man is with [[our]748-our beautiful neighbour]757-our beautiful neighbour , [Miss Stapleton]147-stapleton . And yet the course of true love does not run quite as smoothly as [one]1629-one would under the circumstances expect . To - day , for example , [its]1540-the house surface was broken by a very unexpected ripple , which has caused [[our]748-our friend]1718-our friend considerable perplexity and annoyance .

After the conversation which [I]0-i have quoted about [Barrymore]143-barrymore , [Sir Henry]115-sir henry put on [his]115-sir henry hat and prepared to go out . As a matter of course [I]0-i did the same .

It put [me]0-i in a most awkward position . [I]0-i was at a loss what to say or what to do , and before [I]0-i had made up [my]0-i mind [he]115-sir henry picked up [his]115-sir henry cane and was gone .

But when [I]0-i came to think the matter over [my]0-i conscience reproached [me]0-i bitterly for having on any pretext allowed [him]115-sir henry to go out of [my]0-i sight . [I]0-i imagined what [my]0-i feelings would be if [I]0-i had to return to [you]760-you and to confess that some misfortune had occurred through [my]0-i disregard for [your]760-you instructions . [I]0-i assure [you]760-you [my]0-i cheeks flushed at the very thought . [I]0-i hurried along [the road]423-the road at the top of [my]0-i speed without seeing anything of [Sir Henry]115-sir henry , until [I]0-i came to the point where [the moor path]762-the moor path branches off . There , fearing that perhaps [I]0-i had come in the wrong direction after all , [I]0-i mounted [a hill from which [I]0-i could command a view]763-a hill from which i could command a view - [the same hill which is cut into [the dark quarry]765-the dark quarry]764-the same hill which is cut into the dark quarry . [He]115-sir henry was on [the moor path]762-the moor path about a quarter of a mile off , and [a lady]767-a lady was by [his]115-sir henry side who could only be [Miss Stapleton]147-stapleton . It was clear that there was already an understanding between [them]768-them and that [they]768-them had met by ap- pointment . [They]768-them were walking slowly along in deep conversa- tion , and [I]0-i saw [her]767-a lady making quick little movements of [her]767-a lady hands as if [she]767-a lady were very earnest in what [she]767-a lady was saying , while [he]115-sir henry listened intently , and once or twice shook [his]115-sir henry head in strong dissent . [I]0-i stood among the rocks watching [them]768-them , very much puzzled as to what [I]0-i should do next . To follow [them]768-them and break into [their]768-them intimate conversation seemed to be an outrage , and yet [my]0-i clear duty was never for an instant to let [him]115-sir henry out of [my]0-i sight . To act [the spy]1970-the spy upon [a friend]1754-a friend was a hateful task . Still , [I]0-i could see no better course than to observe [him]115-sir henry from [the hill]771-the hill , and to clear [my]0-i conscience by confessing to [him]115-sir henry afterwards what [I]0-i had done . It is true that if any sudden danger had threatened [him]115-sir henry [I]0-i was too far away to be of use , and yet [I]0-i am sure that [you]772-you will agree with [me]0-i that the position was very difficult , and that there was nothing more which [I]0-i could do .

[[Our]773-their friend]1718-our friend , [Sir Henry]115-sir henry , and [the lady]590-the lady had halted on [the path]1632-the path and were standing deeply absorbed in [their]773-their conversation , when [I]0-i was suddenly aware that [I]0-i was not the only witness of [their]773-their interview . A wisp of green floating in the air caught [my]0-i eye , and another glance showed [me]0-i that it was carried on a stick by [a man who was moving among the broken ground]777-a man who was moving among the broken ground . [He]115-sir henry was very much closer to [the pair]778-the pair than [I]0-i was , and [he]115-sir henry appeared to be moving in [their]778-the pair direction . At this instant [Sir Henry]115-sir henry suddenly drew [Miss Stapleton]147-stapleton to [his]115-sir henry side .
