[The baronet]292-the baronet stood for a minute looking after [them]779-the lovers , and then [he]292-the baronet walked slowly back the way that [he]292-the baronet had come , [his]292-the baronet head hanging , the very picture of dejection .

What all this meant [I]0-i could not imagine , but [I]0-i was deeply ashamed to have witnessed so intimate a scene without [[my]0-i friend]1476-my friend 's knowledge . [I]0-i tried one or two explanations , but , indeed , [I]0-i was completely puzzled [myself]0-i . [[Our]791-our friend]1718-our friend 's title , [his]1718-our friend fortune , [his]1718-our friend age , [his]1718-our friend character , and [his]1718-our friend appearance are all in [his]1718-our friend favour , and [I]0-i know nothing against [him]1718-our friend unless it be this dark fate which runs in [[his]1718-our friend family]1605-his family . [They]2297-they have always been together , and according to [his]1718-our friend account [he]1718-our friend has been [a very lonely man with only [her]2032-his sister as [a companion]341-a companion]2298-a very lonely man with only her as a companion , so that the thought of losing [her]2032-his sister was really terrible to [him]1718-our friend . [He]1718-our friend had not understood , [he]1718-our friend said , that [I]115-sir henry was becoming attached to [her]2032-his sister , but when [he]1718-our friend saw with [his]1718-our friend own eyes that it was really so , and that [she]2032-his sister might be taken away from [him]1718-our friend , it gave [him]1718-our friend such a shock that for a time [he]1718-our friend was not responsible for what [he]1718-our friend said or did . [He]1718-our friend was very sorry for all that had passed , and [he]1718-our friend recognized how foolish and how selfish it was that [he]1718-our friend should imagine that [he]1718-our friend could hold [a beautiful woman like [[his]1718-our friend sister]2032-his sister to [himself]1718-our friend for [her]2032-his sister whole life]2300-a beautiful woman like his sister to himself for her whole life . [He]1718-our friend would withdraw all opposition upon [his]1718-our friend part if [I]115-sir henry would promise for three months to let the matter rest and to be content with cultivating [the lady]590-the lady 's friendship during that time without claiming [her]590-the lady love . This [I]115-sir henry promised , and so the matter rests . "[115-sir henry]

So there is one of [our]798-we small mysteries cleared up . It is something to have touched bottom anywhere in [this bog in which [we]798-we are floundering]799-this bog in which we are floundering . [We]798-we know now why [Stapleton]147-stapleton looked with disfavour upon [[[his]800-his sister]2032-his sister 's suitor]802-his sister 's suitor - even when [that suitor]803-that suitor was so eligible a one as [Sir Henry]115-sir henry . And now [I]0-i pass on to another thread which [I]0-i have extricated out of the tangled skein , the mystery of the sobs in the night , of the tear - stained face of [Mrs. Barrymore]143-barrymore , of the secret journey of [the butler]459-the butler to the western lattice window . Congratulate [me]0-i , [[my]0-i dear]1408-my dear [Holmes]96-holmes , and tell [me]0-i that [I]0-i have not disappointed [you]96-holmes as [an agent]806-an agent - that [you]96-holmes do not regret the confi- dence which [you]96-holmes showed in [me]0-i when [you]96-holmes sent [me]0-i down . All these things have by one night 's work been thoroughly cleared .

[I]0-i have said " by one night 's work , "[0-i] but , in truth , it was by two nights ' work , for on the first [we]807-we drew entirely blank . [I]0-i sat up with [Sir Henry]115-sir henry in [[his]115-sir henry rooms]808-his rooms until nearly three o'clock in the morning , but no sound of any sort did [we]807-we hear except the chiming clock upon the stairs . It was a most melancholy vigil and ended by each of [us]807-we falling asleep in [our]807-we chairs . Fortunately [we]807-we were not discouraged , and [we]807-we determined to try again . The next night [we]807-we lowered the lamp and sat smoking cigarettes without making the least sound . It was incredible how slowly the hours crawled by , and yet [we]807-we were helped through it by the same sort of patient interest which [the hunter]809-the hunter must feel as [he]809-the hunter watches the trap into which [he]809-the hunter hopes the game may wander . One struck , and two , and [we]807-we had almost for the second time given it up in despair when in an instant [we]807-we both sat bolt upright in [our]807-we chairs with all [our]807-we weary senses keenly on the alert once more . [We]807-we had heard the creak of a step in [the passage]711-the passage .

Very stealthily [we]807-we heard it pass along until it died away in the distance . Then [the baronet]292-the baronet gently opened [his]292-the baronet door and [we]807-we set out in pursuit . Already [[our]807-we man]1817-our man had gone round [the gallery]326-the gallery and [the corridor]709-the corridor was all in darkness . Softly [we]807-we stole along untii [we]807-we had come into [the other wing]2113-the other wing . [We]807-we were just in time to catch a glimpse of the tall , black - bearded figure , [his]292-the baronet shoulders rounded as [he]292-the baronet tiptoed down [the passage]711-the passage . Then [he]292-the baronet passed through the same door as before , and the light of the candle framed [it]817-it in the darkness and shot one single yellow beam across the gloom of [the corridor]709-the corridor . [We]807-we shuffled cautiously towards [it]817-it , trying every plank before [we]807-we dared to put [our]807-we whole weight upon it . [We]807-we had taken the precaution of leaving [our]807-we boots behind [us]807-we , but , even so , the old boards snapped and creaked beneath [our]807-we tread . Some- times it seemed impossible that [he]292-the baronet should fail to hear [our]807-we ap- proach . However , [the man]1397-the man is fortunately rather deaf , and [he]1397-the man was entirely preoccupied in that which [he]1397-the man was doing . [We]807-we had arranged no plan of campaign , but [the baronet]292-the baronet is [a man to whom the most direct way]821-a man to whom the most direct way is always the most natural . This , then , was the explanation of the stealthy expeditions at night and the light at the window . [Sir Henry]115-sir henry and [I]0-i both stared at [the woman]836-the woman in amazement . The same thought had crossed [my]0-i own mind . It was not as if [the Barrymores]112-the barrymores had taken [us]843-we into [their]112-the barrymores confidence . " [I]849-i will come , "[849-i] said [I.]849-i

In five minutes [we]843-we were outside the door , starting upon [our]843-we expedition . " Are [you]2360-your armed ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked .

" [I]292-the baronet have a hunting - crop . "[292-the baronet]

" [I]292-the baronet say , [Watson]95-watson , "[292-the baronet] said [the baronet]292-the baronet , " what would [Holmes]96-holmes say to this ? How about that hour of darkness in which the power of evil is exalted ? "[292-the baronet]

As if in answer to [his]292-the baronet words there rose suddenly out of the vast gloom of [the moor]1528-the moor that strange cry which [I]0-i had already heard upon [the borders of [the great Grimpen Mire]2170-the great grimpen mire]853-the borders of the great grimpen mire . It came with the wind through the silence of the night , a long , deep mutter then a rising howl , and then the sad moan in which it died away . Again and again it sounded , the whole air throbbing with it , strident , wild , and menacing . [The baronet]292-the baronet caught [my]0-i sleeve and [his]292-the baronet face glimmered white through the darkness .

" [[My]292-the baronet God]2363-my god , what 's that , [Watson]95-watson ? "[292-the baronet]

" [I]292-the baronet do n't know . It 's a sound [they]2364-they have on [the moor]1528-the moor . [I]292-the baronet heard it once before . "[292-the baronet]

It died away , and an absolute silence closed in upon [us]856-us . [We]856-us stood straining [our]856-us ears , but nothing came .

" [Watson]95-watson , "[292-the baronet] said [the baronet]292-the baronet , " it was the cry of a hound . "[292-the baronet]

[My]0-i blood ran cold in [my]0-i veins , for there was a break in [his]292-the baronet voice which told of the sudden horror which had seized [him]292-the baronet .

[He]292-the baronet groaned and was silent for a few moments .

" A hound it was , "[292-the baronet] [he]292-the baronet said at last , " but it seemed to come from miles away , over yonder , [I]292-the baronet think . "[292-the baronet]

" [Stapleton]147-stapleton was with [me]292-the baronet when [I]292-the baronet heard it last . [He]292-the baronet said that it might be the calling of a strange bird . "[292-the baronet]

" No , no . "[292-the baronet]

" And yet it was one thing to laugh about it in [London]2-london , and it is another to stand out here in the darkness of [the moor]1528-the moor and to hear such a cry as that . " [You]95-watson 'll be all right to - morrow . "[292-the baronet]

" Shall [we]2375-we turn back ? "[292-the baronet]

" No , by thunder ; [we]2375-we have come out to get [[our]2375-we man]1817-our man , and [we]2375-we will do it . [We]2375-we 'll see it through if [all the fiends of the pit]2378-all the fiends of the pit were loose upon [the moor]1528-the moor . "[292-the baronet]

[We]858-we stumbled slowly along in the darkness , with the black loom of [the craggy hills]859-the craggy hills around [us]858-we , and the yellow speck of light burning steadily in front . There is nothing so deceptive as the distance of a light upon a pitch - dark night , and sometimes the glimmer seemed to be far away upon the horizon and sometimes it might have been within a few yards of [us]858-we . But at last [we]858-we could see whence it came , and then [we]858-we knew that [we]858-we were indeed very close . A guttering candle was stuck in a crevice of the rocks which flanked [it]860-it on each side so as to keep the wind from it and also to prevent it from being visible , save in the direction of [Baskerville Hall]115-sir henry . A boulder of granite concealed [our]858-we approach , and crouching behind it [we]858-we gazed over it at the signal light . It was strange to see this single candle burning there in the middle of [the moor]1528-the moor , with no sign of life near [it]860-it - just the one straight yellow flame and the gleam of the rock on each side of it .

" What shall [we]858-we do now ? "[115-sir henry] whispered [Sir Henry]115-sir henry .

" Wait here . [He]862-his must be near [his]862-his light . Let [us]858-we see if [we]858-we can get a glimpse of [him]862-his . "[115-sir henry]

The words were hardly out of [my]0-i mouth when [we]858-we both saw [him]862-his . Over [the rocks]863-the rocks , in the crevice of which the candle burned , there was thrust out an evil yellow face , [a terrible animal face , all seamed and scored with vile passions . Foul with mire , with a bristling beard , and hung with matted hair]864-a terrible animal face , all seamed and scored with vile passions . foul with mire , with a bristling beard , and hung with matted hair , it might well have belonged to [one of those old savages who dwelt in the burrows on [the hillsides]866-the hillsides]865-one of those old savages who dwelt in the burrows on the hillsides . The light beneath [him]862-his was reflected in [his]862-his small , cunning eyes which peered fiercely to right and left through the darkness like [a crafty and savage animal who has heard the steps of the hunters]867-a crafty and savage animal who has heard the steps of the hunters .

Something had evidently aroused [his]862-his suspicions . It may have been that [Barrymore]143-barrymore had some private signal which [we]858-we had neglected to give , or [the fellow]823-the fellow may have had some other reason for thinking that all was not well , but [I]0-i could read [his]862-his fears upon [his]862-his wicked face . Any instant [he]862-his might dash out the light and vanish in the darkness . [I]0-i sprang forward therefore , and [Sir Henry]115-sir henry did the same . At the same moment [the convict]2377-the convict screamed out a curse at [us]858-we and hurled a rock which splintered up against the boulder which had sheltered [us]858-we . [I]0-i caught one glimpse of [his]862-his short , squat , strongly built figure as [he]862-his sprang to [his]862-his feet and turned to run . At the same moment by a lucky chance the moon broke through the clouds . [We]858-we rushed over [the brow of [the hill]771-the hill]870-the brow of the hill , and there was [[our]858-we man]1817-our man running with great speed down the other side , springing over the stones in [his]862-his way with the activity of [a mountain goat]873-a mountain goat . A lucky long shot of [my]0-i revolver might have crippled [him]862-his , but [I]0-i had brought it only to defend [myself]0-i if attacked and not to shoot [an unarmed man who was running away]874-an unarmed man who was running away .

[We]858-we were both [swift runners]875-swift runners and in fairly good training , but [we]858-we soon found that [we]858-we had no chance of overtaking [him]862-his . [We]858-we saw [him]862-his for a long time in the moonlight until [he]862-his was only a small speck moving swiftly among the boulders upon [the side of [a distant hill]877-a distant hill]876-the side of a distant hill . [We]858-we ran and ran until [we]858-we were completely blown , but the space between [us]858-we grew ever wider . Finally [we]858-we stopped and sat panting on two rocks , while [we]858-we watched [him]862-his disappearing in the distance .

And it was at this moment that there occurred a most strange and unexpected thing . [We]858-we had risen from [our]858-we rocks and were turning to go [home]1520-home , having abandoned the hopeless chase . The moon was low upon the right , and the jagged pinnacle of [a granite tor]879-a granite tor stood up against the lower curve of [its]879-a granite tor silver disc . There , outlined as black as an ebony statue on that shining background , [I]0-i saw the figure of [a man upon the tor]880-a man upon the tor . Do not think that it was a delusion , [Holmes]96-holmes . [I]0-i assure [you]96-holmes that [I]0-i have never in [my]0-i life seen anything more clearly . As far as [I]0-i could judge , [the figure]881-the figure was that of [a tall , thin man]882-a tall , thin man . [He]882-a tall , thin man stood with [his]882-a tall , thin man legs a little separated , [his]882-a tall , thin man arms folded , [his]882-a tall , thin man head bowed , as if [he]882-a tall , thin man were brooding over [that enormous wilderness of peat and granite which lay before [him]882-a tall , thin man]883-that enormous wilderness of peat and granite which lay before him . [He]882-a tall , thin man might have been the very spirit of [that terrible place]884-that terrible place . It was not [the convict]2377-the convict . [This man]705-this man was far from the place where [the latter]210-the latter had disappeared . Besides , [he]882-a tall , thin man was [a much taller man]888-a much taller man . With a cry of surprise [I]0-i pointed [him]705-this man out to [the baronet]292-the baronet , but in the instant during which [I]0-i had turned to grasp [his]292-the baronet arm [the man]1397-the man was gone . There was the sharp pinnacle of granite still cutting the lower edge of the moon , but [its]891-its peak bore no trace of that silent and motionless figure .

[I]0-i wished to go in that direction and to search [the tor]892-the tor , but [it]892-the tor was some distance away . [The baronet]292-the baronet 's nerves were still quivering from that cry , which recalled the dark story of [[his]292-the baronet family]1605-his family , and [he]292-the baronet was not in the mood for fresh adventures . [He]292-the baronet had not seen [this lonely man upon the tor]895-this lonely man upon the tor and could not feel the thrill which [his]292-the baronet strange presence and [his]292-the baronet commanding attitude had given to [me]0-i . " [A warder]2380-a warder , no doubl , "[292-the baronet] said [he]292-the baronet . " [The moor]1528-the moor has been thick with [them]2382-them since [this fellow]2383-this fellow escaped . "[292-the baronet] Well , perhaps [his]292-the baronet explanation may be the right one , but [I]0-i should like to have some further proof of it . To - day [we]896-we mean to communicate to [the Princetown people where [they]897-the princetown people where they should look for their missing man should look for [[their]897-the princetown people where they should look for their missing man missing man]898-their missing man]897-the princetown people where they should look for their missing man , but it is hard lines that [we]896-we have not actually had the triumph of bringing [him]898-their missing man back as [[our]896-we own prisoner]899-our own prisoner . Such are the adventures of last night , and [you]900-you must acknowledge , [[my]0-i dear]1408-my dear [Holmes]96-holmes , that [I]0-i have done [you]900-you very well in the matter of a report . Much of what [I]0-i tell [you]900-you is no doubt quite irrelevant , but still [I]0-i feel that it is best that [I]0-i should let [you]900-you have all the facts and leave [you]900-you to select for [yourself]900-you those which will be of most service to [you]900-you in helping [you]900-you to [your]900-you conclusilons . [We]896-we are certainly making some prog- ress . So far as [the Barrymores]112-the barrymores go [we]896-we have found the motive of [their]112-the barrymores actions , and that has cleared up the situation very much . But [the moor]1528-the moor with [its]1528-the moor mysteries and [its strange inhabitants]903-its strange inhabitants re- mains as inscrutable as ever . Perhaps in [my]0-i next [I]0-i may be able to throw some light upon this also . Best of all would it be if [you]900-you could come down to [us]896-we . In any case [you]900-you will hear from [me]0-i again in the course of the next few days .

Chapter 10

Extract from the Diary of [Dr. Watson]95-watson

So far [I]0-i have been able to quote from the reports which [I]0-i have forwarded during these early days to [Sherlock Holmes]96-holmes . Now , however , [I]0-i have arrived at a point in [my]0-i narrative where [I]0-i am compelled to abandon this method and to trust once more to [my]0-i recollections , aided by the diary which [I]0-i kept at the time . A few extracts from the latter will carry [me]0-i on to those scenes which are indelibly fixed in every detail upon [my]0-i memory . [I]0-i proceed , then , from the morning which followed [our]896-we abortive chase of [the convict]2377-the convict and [our]896-we other strange experiences upon [the moor]1528-the moor .

October 16th . A dull and foggy day with a drizzle of rain . [The house]1540-the house is banked in with rolling clouds , which rise now and then to show the dreary curves of [the moor]1528-the moor , with thin , silver veins upon the sides of [the hills]908-the hills , and the distant boulders gleaming where the light strikes upon [their]909-their wet faces . It is melancholy outside and in . [The baronet]292-the baronet is in a black reaction after the excitements of the night . [I]0-i am conscious [myself]0-i of a weight at [my]0-i heart and a feeling of impending danger - ever present dan- ger , which is the more terrible because [I]0-i am unable to define it .

And have [I]0-i not cause for such a feeling ? Consider the long sequence of incidents which have all pointed to some sinister influence which is at work around [us]896-we . There is the death of [the last occupant of the Hall]911-the last occupant of the hall , fulfilling so exactly the conditions of the family legend , and there are the repeated reports from [peas- ants]912-peas- ants of the appearance of a strange creature upon [the moor]1528-the moor . Twice [I]0-i have with [my]0-i own ears heard the sound which resem- bled the distant baying of a hound . It is incredible , impossible , that it should really be outside the ordinary laws of nature . A spectral hound which leaves material footmarks and fills the air with its howling is surely not to be thought of . [Stapleton]147-stapleton may fall in with such a superstition , and [Mortimer]94-dr. mortimer also , but if [I]0-i have one quality upon earth it is common sense , and nothing will persuade [me]0-i to believe in such a thing . To do so would be to descend to the level of [these poor peasants , who are not content with a mere fiend dog]914-these poor peasants , who are not content with a mere fiend dog but must needs describe [him]915-him with hell - fire shooting from [his]915-him mouth and eyes . [Holmes]96-holmes would not listen to such fancies , and [I]0-i am [[his]96-holmes agent]916-his agent . But facts are facts , and [I]0-i have twice heard this crying upon [the moor]1528-the moor . Suppose that there were really some huge hound loose upon [it]1528-the moor ; that would go far to explain everything . But where could such a hound lie concealed , where did it get [its]918-its food , where did it come from , how was it that [no one]1622-no one saw [it]918-its by day ? It must be confessed that the natural explana- tion offers almost as many difficulties as the other . And always , apart from the hound , there is the fact of the human agency in [London]2-london , [the man in the cab]920-the man in the cab , and the letter which warned [Sir Henry]115-sir henry against [the moor]1528-the moor . This at least was real , but it might have been the work of [a protecting friend]922-a protecting friend as easily as of [an enemy]923-an enemy . Where is [that friend]924-that friend or [enemy]925-enemy now ? Has [he]920-the man in the cab remained in [London]2-london , or has [he]920-the man in the cab followed [us]926-us down [here]1456-here ? Could [he]920-the man in the cab - could [he]920-the man in the cab be [the stranger whom [I]0-i saw upon [the tor]892-the tor]928-the stranger whom i saw upon the tor ?

It is true that [I]0-i have had only the one glance at [him]920-the man in the cab , and yet there are some things to which [I]0-i am ready to swear . [He]920-the man in the cab is [no one whom [I]0-i have seen down here]930-no one whom i have seen down here , and [I]0-i have now met [all the neighbours]931-all the neighbours . The figure was far taller than that of [Stapleton]147-stapleton , far thinner than that of [Frankland]116-frankland . [Barrymore]143-barrymore it might possibly have been , but [we]926-us had left [him]920-the man in the cab behind [us]926-us , and [I]0-i am certain that [he]920-the man in the cab could not have followed [us]926-us . [A stranger then]932-a stranger then is still dogging [us]926-us , just as [a stranger]933-a stranger dogged [us]926-us in [London]2-london . [We]926-us have never shaken [him]920-the man in the cab off . If [I]0-i could lay [my]0-i hands upon [that man]1846-that man , then at last [we]926-us might find [ourselves]926-us at the end of all [our]926-us difficulties . To this one purpose [I]0-i must now devote all [my]0-i energies .

[My]0-i first impulse was to tell [Sir Henry]115-sir henry all [my]0-i plans . [My]0-i second and wisest one is to play [my]0-i own game and speak as little as possible ta [anyone]1593-anyone . [He]115-sir henry is silent and distrait . [His]115-sir henry nerves have been strangely shaken by that sound upon [the moor]1528-the moor . [I]0-i will say nothing to add to [his]115-sir henry anxieties , but [I]0-i will take [my]0-i own steps to attain [my]0-i own end .

[We]926-us had a small scene this morning after breakfast . [Barrymore]143-barrymore asked leave to speak with [Sir Henry]115-sir henry , and [they]937-they were closeted in [[his]115-sir henry study]743-his study some little time . Sitting in [the billiard - room]939-the billiard - room [I]0-i more than once heard the sound of voices raised , and [I]0-i had a pretty good idea what the point was which was under discussion . After a time [the baronet]292-the baronet opened [his]292-the baronet door and called for [me]0-i .

" [Barrymore]143-barrymore considers that [he]115-sir henry has a grievance , "[292-the baronet] [he]292-the baronet said . " How do [you]1459-sir know this , [Barrymore]143-barrymore ? "[292-the baronet]

" Let [Holmes]96-holmes know all about it at once . It will give [him]96-holmes the clue for which [he]96-holmes has been seeking . [I]0-i am much mistaken if it does not bring [him]96-holmes down . "[0-i]

[I]0-i went at once to [[my]0-i room]708-my room and drew up [my]0-i report of the morning 's conversation for [Holmes]96-holmes . No doubt [his]96-holmes blackmailing case is absorbing all [his]96-holmes faculties . And yet this new factor must surely arrest [his]96-holmes attention and renew [his]96-holmes interest . [I]0-i wish that [he]96-holmes were here .

October 17th . All day to - day the rain poured down , rustling on the ivy and dripping from the eaves . [I]0-i thought of [the convict]2377-the convict out upon [the bleak , cold , shelterless moor]951-the bleak , cold , shelterless moor . [Poor devil]952-poor devil ! Whatever [his]952-poor devil crimes , [he]952-poor devil has suffered something to atone for them . And then [I]0-i thought of [that other one]953-that other one - the face in [the cab]309-the cab , [the figure against the moon]955-the figure against the moon . Was [he]953-that other one also out in that deluged - [the unseen watcher]956-the unseen watcher , [the man of darkness]957-the man of darkness ? In the evening [I]0-i put on [my]0-i waterproof and [I]0-i walked far upon [the sodden moor]958-the sodden moor , full of dark imaginings , the rain beating upon [my]0-i face and the wind whis- tling about [my]0-i ears . God help those who wander into [the great mire]558-the great mire now , for even [the firm uplands]960-the firm uplands are becoming a morass . [I]0-i found [the black tor upon which [I]0-i had seen [the solitary watcher]962-the solitary watcher]961-the black tor upon which i had seen the solitary watcher , and from [its]961-the black tor upon which i had seen the solitary watcher craggy summit [I]0-i looked out [myself]0-i across [the melancholy downs]963-the melancholy downs . Rain squalls drifted across their russet face , and the heavy , slate - coloured clouds hung low over [the land-]964-the land- scape , trailing in gray wreaths down [the sides of [the fantastic hills]966-the fantastic hills]965-the sides of the fantastic hills . In [the distant hollow on the left]967-the distant hollow on the left , half hidden by the mist , [the two thin towers of [Baskerville Hall]115-sir henry]968-the two thin towers of baskerville hall rose above the trees . Nowhere was there any trace of [that lonely man whom [I]0-i had seen on [the same spot]973-the same spot two nights before]972-that lonely man whom i had seen on the same spot two nights before .

As [I]0-i walked back [I]0-i was overtaken by [Dr. Mortimer]94-dr. mortimer driving in [[his]94-dr. mortimer dog - cart]974-his dog - cart over [a rough moorland track]975-a rough moorland track which led from [the outlying farmhouse of Foulmire]976-the outlying farmhouse of foulmire . [He]94-dr. mortimer insisted upon [my]0-i climbing into [his]94-dr. mortimer dog - cart , and [he]94-dr. mortimer gave [me]0-i a lift homeward . [I]0-i found [him]94-dr. mortimer much troubled over the disappearance of [his]94-dr. mortimer little spaniel . It had wandered on to [the moor]1528-the moor and had never come back . " How does [she]152-coombe tracey live ? "[94-dr. mortimer]

[He]981-he wanted to know the object of [my]0-i inquiries , but [I]0-i managed to satisfy [his]981-he curiosity without telling [him]981-he too much , for there is no reason why [we]982-our should take [anyone]1593-anyone into [our]982-our confidence . [I]0-i am certainly developing the wisdom of the serpent , for when [Mortimer]94-dr. mortimer pressed [his]94-dr. mortimer questions to an inconvenient extent [I]0-i asked [him]94-dr. mortimer casually to what type [Frank- land]156-frank- land 's skull belonged , and so heard nothing but craniology for the rest of [our]982-our drive . [I]0-i have not lived for years with [Sherlock Holmes]96-holmes for nothing .

[I]0-i have only one other incident to record upon this tempestuous and melancholy day . This was [my]0-i conversation with [Barrymore]143-barrymore just now , which gives [me]0-i one more strong card which [I]0-i can play in due time .

[Mortimer]94-dr. mortimer had stayed to dinner , and [he]94-dr. mortimer and [the baronet]292-the baronet played ecarte afterwards . "[989-i.] When [the butler]459-the butler had gone [I]0-i walked over to the black window , and [I]0-i looked through a blurred pane at the driving clouds and at the tossing outline of the wind - swept trees . It is a wild night indoors , and what must it be in [a stone hut upon [the moor]1528-the moor]991-a stone hut upon the moor . There , in [that hut upon [the moor]1528-the moor]994-that hut upon the moor , seems to lie the very centre of that problem which has vexed [me]0-i so sorely . [I]0-i swear that another day shall not have passed before [I]0-i have done all [that man]1846-that man can do to reach the heart of the mystery .

Chapter 11

The Man on [the Tor]66-the tor

The extract from [my]0-i private diary which forms the last chapter has brought [my]0-i narrative up to the eighteenth of October , a time when these strange events began to move swiftly towards their terrible conclusion . The incidents of the next few days are indelibly graven upon [my]0-i recollection , and [I]0-i can tell [them]997-them without reference to the notes made at the time . [I]0-i start them from the day which succeeded that upon which [I]0-i had established two facts of great importance , the one that [Mrs. Laura Lyons of Coombe Tracey]152-coombe tracey had written to [Sir Charles Baskerville]100-sir charles and made an appointment with [him]100-sir charles at [the very place and hour that [he]100-sir charles met [his]100-sir charles death]998-the very place and hour that he met his death , the other that [the lurking man upon [the moor]1528-the moor]999-the lurking man upon the moor was to be found among [the stone huts upon [the hillside]2489-the hillside]1001-the stone huts upon the hillside . With these two facts in [my]0-i possession [I]0-i felt that either [my]0-i intelligence or [my]0-i courage must be deficient if [I]0-i could not throw some further light upon [these dark places]1003-these dark places .

[I]0-i had no opportunity to tell [the baronet]292-the baronet what [I]0-i had learned about [Mrs. Lyons]152-coombe tracey upon the evening before , for [Dr. Mortimer]94-dr. mortimer remained with [him]292-the baronet at cards until it was very late . At breakfast , however , [I]0-i informed [him]292-the baronet about [my]0-i discovery and asked [him]292-the baronet whether [he]292-the baronet would care to accompany [me]0-i to [Coombe Tracey]152-coombe tracey . At first [he]292-the baronet was very eager to come , but on second thoughts it seemed to [both of [us]1005-both of us]1005-both of us that if [I]0-i went alone the results might be better . The more formal [we]1005-both of us made the visit the less information [we]1005-both of us might obtain . [I]0-i left [Sir Henry]115-sir henry behind , therefore , not without some prickings of conscience , and drove off upon [my]0-i new quest .

When [I]0-i reached [Coombe Tracey]152-coombe tracey [I]0-i told [Perkins]139-perkins to put up [the horses]1006-the horses , and [I]0-i made inquiries for [the lady whom [I]0-i had come to interrogate]1007-the lady whom i had come to interrogate . [I]0-i had no difficulty in finding [[her]1007-the lady whom i had come to interrogate rooms]1008-her rooms , which were central and well appointed . [A maid]1009-a maid showed [me]0-i in without cere- mony , and as [I]0-i entered [the sitting - room]267-the sitting - room [a lady]767-a lady , who was sitting before a Remington typewriter , sprang up with a pleasant smile of welcome . [Her]1007-the lady whom i had come to interrogate face fell , however , when [she]1007-the lady whom i had come to interrogate saw that [I]0-i was [a stranger]933-a stranger , and [she]1007-the lady whom i had come to interrogate sat down again and asked [me]0-i the object of [my]0-i visit .

The first impression left by [Mrs. Lyons]152-coombe tracey was one of extreme beauty . [Her]1007-the lady whom i had come to interrogate eyes and hair were of the same rich hazel colour , and [her]1007-the lady whom i had come to interrogate cheeks , though considerably freckled , were flushed with the exquisite bloom of [the brunette]1013-the brunette , the dainty pink which lurks at the heart of the sulphur rose . Admiration was , [I]0-i repeat , the first impression . But the second was criticism . There was some- thing subtly wrong with the face , some coarseness of expres- sion , some hardness , perhaps , of eye , some looseness of lip which marred its perfect beauty . But these , of course , are after- thoughts . At the moment [I]0-i was simply conscious that [I]0-i was in the presence of [a very handsome woman]1014-a very handsome woman , and that [she]1014-a very handsome woman was asking [me]0-i the reasons for [my]0-i visit . [I]0-i had not quite understood until that instant how delicate [my]0-i mission was .

" [I]0-i have the pleasure , "[0-i] said [I]0-i , " of knowing [[your]590-the lady father]2494-your father . "[0-i] It was a clumsy introduction , and [the lady]590-the lady made [me]0-i feel it .

" There is nothing in common between [[my]590-the lady father]1501-my father and [me]590-the lady , "[590-the lady] [she]590-the lady said . " [I]590-the lady owe [him]1501-my father nothing , and [[his]1501-my father friends]1422-his friends are not [mine]590-the lady . "[590-the lady]

" It was about [the late Sir Charles Baskerville]100-sir charles that [I]590-the lady have come here to see [you]590-the lady . "[590-the lady]

The freckles started out on [the lady]590-the lady 's face .

" [You]590-the lady knew [him]1501-my father , did [you]590-the lady not ? "[590-the lady]

" Did [you]590-the lady ever write to [Sir Charles]100-sir charles asking [him]100-sir charles to meet [you]590-the lady ? "[0-i] [I]0-i continued .

" Surely [your]590-the lady memory deceives [you]590-the lady , "[0-i] said [I.]0-i " [I]0-i could even quote a passage of [your]590-the lady letter . It ran ' Please , please , as [you]1459-sir are [a gentleman]1705-a gentleman , burn this letter , and be at the gate by ten o'clock . ' "[0-i]

[I]0-i thought that [she]590-the lady had fainted , but [she]590-the lady recovered [herself]590-the lady by a supreme effort .

" [You]0-i do [Sir Charles]100-sir charles an injustice . [He]100-sir charles did burn the letter . But sometimes a letter may be legible even when burned . [You]0-i acknowledge now that [you]0-i wrote it ? "[0-i]

" Yes , [I]590-the lady did write it , "[590-the lady] [she]590-the lady cried , pouring out [her]590-the lady soul in a torrent of words . " [I]590-the lady did write it . [I]590-the lady believed that if [I]590-the lady had an interview [I]590-the lady could gain [his]100-sir charles help , so [I]590-the lady asked [him]100-sir charles to meet [me]590-the lady . "[590-the lady]

" But why at such an hour ? "[0-i]

" Because [I]590-the lady had only just learned that [he]100-sir charles was going to [London]2-london next day and might be away for months . There were reasons why [I]590-the lady could not get [there]1461-there earlier . "[590-the lady]

" [I]590-the lady never went . "[590-the lady]

" [Mrs. Lyons]152-coombe tracey ! "[0-i]

The sun was already sinking when [I]0-i reached [the summit of [the hill]771-the hill]1080-the summit of the hill , and [the long slopes beneath [me]0-i]1082-the long slopes beneath me were all golden - green on one side and gray shadow on the other . Over [the wide expanse]1083-the wide expanse there was no sound and no movement . One great gray bird , a gull or curlew , soared aloft in [the blue heaven]1084-the blue heaven . As [I]0-i approached [the hut]1043-the hut , walking as warily as [Stapleton]117-stapleton would do when with poised net [he]117-stapleton drew near the settled butterfly , [I]0-i satisfied [myself]0-i that [the place]2105-the place had indeed been used as a habita- tion . [A vague pathway among the boulders]1094-a vague pathway among the boulders led to the dilapidated opening which served as a door . All was silent within . [The unknown]1095-the unknown might be lurking there , or [he]2252-the boy might be prowling on [the moor]1528-the moor . [My]0-i nerves tingled with the sense of adventure . Throwing aside [my]0-i cigarette , [I]0-i closed [my]0-i hand upon the butt of [my]0-i revolver and , walking swiftly up to the door , [I]0-i looked in . [The place]2105-the place was empty .

But there were ample signs that [I]0-i had not come upon a false scent . This was certainly where [the man]1397-the man lived . Some blankets rolled in a waterproof lay upon that very stone slab upon which [neolithic man]2191-neolithic man had once slumbered . The ashes of a fire were heaped in a rude grate . Beside [it]2105-the place lay some cooking utensils and a bucket half - full of water . A litter of empty tins showed that [the place]2105-the place had been occupied for some time , and [I]0-i saw , as [my]0-i eyes became accustomed to the checkered light , a pannikin and a half - full bottle of spirits standing in the corner . In the middle of [the hut]1043-the hut a flat stone served the purpose of a table , and upon this stood a small cloth bundle - the same , no doubt , which [I]0-i had seen through the telescope upon the shoulder of [the boy]2252-the boy . It contained a loaf of bread , a tinned tongue , and two tins of preserved peaches . As [I]0-i set it down again , after having examined it , [my]0-i heart leaped to see that beneath it there lay a sheet of paper with writing upon it . [I]0-i raised it , and this was what [I]0-i read , roughly scrawled in pencil : " [Dr. Watson]95-watson has gone to [Coombe Tracey]152-coombe tracey . "[0-i]

For a minute [I]0-i stood there with the paper in [my]0-i hands thinking out the meaning of this curt message . It was [I]0-i , then , and not [Sir Henry]115-sir henry , who was being aogged by [this secret man]1103-this secret man . [He]115-sir henry had not followed [me]0-i [himself]115-sir henry , but [he]115-sir henry had set [an agent]806-an agent - [the boy]2252-the boy , perhaps - upon [my]0-i track , and this was [his]115-sir henry report . Possibly [I]0-i had taken no step since [I]0-i had been upon [the moor]1528-the moor which had not been observed and reported . Always there was this feeling of an unseen force , a fine net drawn round [us]1107-us with infinite skill and delicacy , holding [us]1107-us so lightly that it was only at some supreme moment that [one]1629-one realized that one was indeed - entangled in its meshes .

If there was one report there might be [others]526-others , so [I]0-i looked round [the hut]1043-the hut in search of [them]526-others . There was no trace , however , of anything of the kind , nor could [I]0-i discover any sign which might indicate the character or intentions of [the man who lived in this singular place , save that [he]115-sir henry must be of Spartan habits and cared little for the comforts of life]1111-the man who lived in this singular place , save that he must be of spartan habits and cared little for the comforts of life . When [I]0-i thought of the heavy rains and looked at the gaping roof [I]0-i understood how strong and immutable must be the purpose which had kept [him]115-sir henry in [that inhospitable abode]1112-that inhospitable abode . Was [he]115-sir henry [[our]1107-us malignant enemy]1113-our malignant enemy , or was [he]115-sir henry by chance [[our]1107-us guardian angel]1114-our guardian angel ? [I]0-i swore that [I]0-i would not leave [the hut]1043-the hut until [I]0-i knew .

Outside the sun was sinking low and the west was blazing with scarlet and gold . [Its]1116-its reflection was shot back in ruddy patches by [the distant pools which lay amid [the great Grimpen Mire]53-the great grimpen mire]1117-the distant pools which lay amid the great grimpen mire . There were [the two towers of [Baskerville Hall]115-sir henry]1118-the two towers of baskerville hall , and there a distant blur of smoke which marked [the village of Grimpen]1119-the village of grimpen . All was sweet and mellow and peaceful in the golden evening light , and yet as [I]0-i looked at [them]1122-them [my]0-i soul shared none of the peace of Nature but quivered at the vagueness and the terror of that interview which every instant was bringing nearer . With tingling nerves but a fixed purpose , [I]0-i sat in [the dark recess of [the hut]1043-the hut]1123-the dark recess of the hut and waited with sombre patience for the coming of [its tenant]1044-its tenant .

And then at last [I]0-i heard [him]1044-its tenant . Far away came the sharp clink of a boot striking upon a stone . Then another and yet another , coming nearer and nearer . [I]0-i shrank back into the darkest corner and cocked the pistol in [my]0-i pocket , determined not to discover [myself]0-i until [I]0-i had an opportunity of seeing something of [the stranger]1028-the stranger . There was a long pause which showed that [he]1044-its tenant had stopped . Then once more the footsteps approached and a shadow fell across the opening of [the hut]1043-the hut .

" Can [you]96-holmes see anything ? "[96-holmes]

" But , hark , what is that ? "[96-holmes]

A low moan had fallen upon [our]1147-we ears . There it was again upon [our]1147-we left ! On that side a ridge of rocks ended in a sheer cliff which overlooked [a stone - strewn slope]1153-a stone - strewn slope . Not a whisper , not a rustle , rose now from the dark figure over which [we]1147-we stooped . [Holmes]96-holmes laid [his]96-holmes hand upon [him]96-holmes and held it up again with an exclamation of horror . There was no chance of either of [us]1147-we forgetting that peculiar ruddy tweed suit - the very one which [he]96-holmes had worn on the first morning that [we]1147-we had seen [him]96-holmes in [Baker Street]24-baker street . [We]1147-we caught the one clear glimpse of it , and then the match flickered and went out , even as the hope had gone out of [our]1147-we souls . [Holmes]96-holmes groaned , and [his]96-holmes face glimmered white through the darkness .

" [The brute]2634-the brute ! [the brute]2634-the brute ! "[0-i] [I]0-i cried with clenched hands . " Oh [Holmes]96-holmes , [I]0-i shall never forgive [myself]0-i for having left [him]96-holmes to [his]96-holmes fate . "[0-i]

"[96-holmes]

" [Our]1230-we case becomes rounded off , and difficulty after difficulty thins away in front of [us]1230-we , "[96-holmes] said [Holmes]96-holmes as [we]1230-we stood waiting for the arrival of [the express]1231-the express from [town]1420-town . " [I]96-holmes shall soon be in the position of being able to put into a single connected narrative one of the most singular and sensational crimes of modern times . [The London express]1233-the london express came roaring into [the station]2003-the station , and a small , wiry bulldog of [a man]1619-a man had sprung from [a first - class carriage]362-a first - class carriage . Chapter 14

The Hound of [the Baskervilles]92-the baskervilles

One of [Sherlock Holmes]96-holmes 's defects - if , indeed , [one]1629-one may call it a defect - was that [he]96-holmes was exceedingly loath to communicate [his]96-holmes full plans to [any other person]1242-any other person until the instant of [their]1243-their fulfilment . Partly it came no doubt from [his]96-holmes own masterful nature , which loved to dominate and surprise [those who were around [him]96-holmes]1244-those who were around him . Partly also from [his]96-holmes professional caution , which urged [him]96-holmes never to take any chances . The result , however , was very trying for those who were acting as [[his]96-holmes agents]1245-his agents and [assistants]1246-assistants . [I]0-i had often suffered under it , but never more so than during that long drive in the darkness . The great ordeal was in front of [us]1247-we ; at last [we]1247-we were about to make [our]1247-we final effort , and yet [Holmes]96-holmes had said nothing , and [I]0-i could only surmise what [his]96-holmes course of action would be . [My]0-i nerves thrilled with anticipation when at last the cold wind upon [our]1247-we faces and the dark , void spaces on either side of [the narrow road]1248-the narrow road told [me]0-i that [we]1247-we were back upon [the moor]1528-the moor once again . Every stride of the horses and every turn of the wheels was taking [us]1247-we nearer to [our]1247-we supreme adventure .

[Our]1247-we conversation was hampered by the presence of [the driver of [the hired wagonette]1251-the hired wagonette]1250-the driver of the hired wagonette , so that [we]1247-we were forced to talk of trivial matters when [our]1247-we nerves were tense with emotion and anticipa- tion . It was a relief to [me]0-i , after that unnatural restraint , when [we]1247-we at last passed [[Frankland]116-frankland 's house]1252-frankland 's house and knew that [we]1247-we were drawing near to [the Hall]1521-the hall and to the scene of action . [We]1247-we did not drive up to the door but got down near the gate of [the avenue]431-the avenue . [I]0-i have said that over [the great Grimpen Mire]2170-the great grimpen mire there hung a dense , white fog . It was drifting slowly in [our]1281-we direction and banked itself up like a wall on that side of [us]1281-we , low but thick and well defined . The moon shone on [it]2170-the great grimpen mire , and it looked like a great shimmering ice - field , with the heads of the distant tors as rocks borne upon its surface . [Holmes]96-holmes 's face was turned towards it , and [he]96-holmes muttered impatiently as [he]96-holmes watched its sluggish drift .

" [It]2170-the great grimpen mire 's moving towards [us]1281-we , [Watson]95-watson . "[96-holmes]

" Is that serious ? "[96-holmes]

The night was clear and fine above [us]1281-we . The stars shone cold and bright , while a half - moon bathed the whole scene in a soft , uncertain light . Before [us]1281-we lay [the dark bulk of [the house]1540-the house]1282-the dark bulk of the house , [its]1540-the house serrated roof and bristling chimneys hard outlined against the silver - spangled sky . Broad bars of golden light from the lower windows stretched across [the orchard]1276-the orchard and [the moor]1528-the moor . One of them was suddenly shut off . [The servants]1286-the servants had left [the kitchen]2809-the kitchen . There only remained the lamp in [the dining - room]2804-the dining - room where [the two men]1289-the two men , [the muderous host]1290-the muderous host and [the unconscious guest]1291-the unconscious guest , still chatted over [their]1289-the two men cigars .

Every minute that white woolly plain which covered [one - half of [the moor]1528-the moor]1292-one - half of the moor was drifting closer and closer to [the house]1540-the house . Already the first thin wisps of it were curling across the golden square of the lighted window . The farther wall of [the orchard]1276-the orchard was already invisible , and the trees were standing out of a swirl of white vapour . As [we]1281-we watched it the fog - wreaths came crawling round both corners of [the house]1540-the house and rolled slowly into one dense bank on which the upper floor and the roof floated like a strange ship upon [a shadowy sea]1297-a shadowy sea . [Holmes]96-holmes struck [his]96-holmes hand passionately upon [the rock in front of [us]1281-we]1298-the rock in front of us and stamped [his]96-holmes feet in [his]96-holmes impatience .

" [We]1281-we are going too far , "[96-holmes] said [Holmes]96-holmes . " [We]1281-we dare not take the chance of [his]2810-he being overtaken before [he]2810-he can reach [us]1281-we . " Thank [God]104-god , [I]96-holmes think that [I]96-holmes hear [him]1303-the man whom we were await- ing coming . "[96-holmes]

A sound of quick steps broke the silence of [the moor]1528-the moor . Crouch- ing among the stones [we]1281-we stared intently at the silver - tipped bank in front of [us]1281-we . The steps grew louder , and through the fog , as through a curtain , there stepped [the man whom [we]1281-we were await- ing]1303-the man whom we were await- ing . [He]1303-the man whom we were await- ing looked round [him]1303-the man whom we were await- ing in surprise as [he]1303-the man whom we were await- ing emerged into the clear , starlit night . Then [he]1303-the man whom we were await- ing came swiftly along [the path]1632-the path , passed close to where [we]1281-we lay , and went on up the long slope behind [us]1281-we . " Hist ! "[96-holmes] cried [Holmes]96-holmes , and [I]0-i heard the sharp click of a cock- ing pistol . " Look out ! It 's coming ! "[96-holmes]

There was a thin , crisp , continuous patter from somewhere in the heart of [that crawling bank]1306-that crawling bank . The cloud was within fifty yards of where [we]1281-we lay , and [we]1281-we glared at it , all three , uncertain what horror was about to break from the heart of it . [I]0-i was at [Holmes]96-holmes 's elbow , and [I]0-i glanced for an instant at [his]1303-the man whom we were await- ing face . [It]1307-it was pale and exultant , [his]1303-the man whom we were await- ing eyes shining brightly in the moonlight . But [sud- denly]169-sud- denly [they]169-sud- denly started forward in a rigid , fixed stare , and [his]1303-the man whom we were await- ing lips parted in amazement . At the same instant [Lestrade]166-lestrade gave a yell of terror and threw [himself]166-lestrade face downward upon the ground . [I]0-i sprang to [my]0-i feet , [my]0-i inert hand grasping [my]0-i pistol , [my]0-i mind paralyzed by the dreadful shape which had sprung out upon [us]1281-we from the shadows of the fog . A hound it was , an enormous coal - black hound , but not such a hound as mortal eyes have ever seen . Fire burst from its open mouth , its eyes glowed with a smouldering glare , its muzzle and hackles and dewlap were outlined in flickering flame . Never in the delirious dream of a disordered brain could anything more savage , more appalling , more hellish be conceived than that dark form and savage face which broke upon [us]1281-we out of the wall of fog .

With long bounds [the huge black creatwe]1308-the huge black creatwe was leaping down [the track]602-the track , following hard upon the footsteps of [[our]1281-we friend]1718-our friend . So paralyzed were [we]1281-we by the apparition that [we]1281-we allowed [him]1718-our friend to pass before [we]1281-we had recovered [our]1281-we nerve . Then [Holmes]96-holmes and [I]0-i both fired together , and the creature gave a hideous howl , which showed that one at least had hit [him]1718-our friend . [He]1718-our friend did not pause , however , but bounded onward . Far away on the path [we]1281-we saw [Sir Henry]115-sir henry looking back , [his]115-sir henry face white in the moonlight , [his]115-sir henry hands raised in horror , glaring helplessly at the frightful thing which was hunt- ing [him]115-sir henry down .

But that cry of pain from the hound had blown all [our]1281-we fears to the winds . If [he]115-sir henry was vulnerable [he]115-sir henry was mortal , and if [we]1281-we could wound [him]115-sir henry [we]1281-we could kill [him]115-sir henry . Never have [I]0-i seen [a man]1619-a man run as [Holmes]96-holmes ran that night . [I]0-i am [reckoned fleet of foot]1312-reckoned fleet of foot , but [he]1718-our friend outpaced [me]0-i as much as [I]0-i outpaced [the little professional]1313-the little professional . In front of [us]1281-we as [we]1281-we flew up [the track]602-the track [we]1281-we heard scream after scream from [Sir Henry]115-sir henry and the deep roar of the hound . [I]0-i was in time to see the beast spring upon [[its]1315-its victim]1316-its victim , hurl [him]1316-its victim to the ground , and worry at [his]1316-its victim throat . But the next instant [Holmes]96-holmes had emptied five barrels of [his]96-holmes revolver into the creature 's flank . With a last howl of agony and a vicious snap in the air , it rolled upon its back , four feet pawing furiously , and then fell limp upon its side . [I]0-i stooped , panting , and pressed [my]0-i pistol to the dreadful , shimmering head , but it was useless to press the trigger . The giant hound was dead .

[Sir Henry]115-sir henry lay insensible where [he]115-sir henry had fallen . [We]1281-we tore away [his]115-sir henry collar , and [Holmes]96-holmes breathed a prayer of gratitude when [we]1281-we saw . that there was no sign of a wound and that the rescue had been in time . Already [[our]1281-we friend]1718-our friend 's eyelids shivered and [he]115-sir henry made a feeble effort to move . " [[My]166-lestrade God]2363-my god ! "[166-lestrade] [he]166-lestrade whispered . " What was it ? What , in heaven 's name , was it ? "[166-lestrade]

In mere size and strength it was a terrible creature which was lying stretched before [us]1281-we . [It]1319-it was not [a pure bloodhound]1320-a pure bloodhound and it was not [a pure mastiff]1321-a pure mastiff ; but it appeared to be a combination of the two - gaunt , savage , and as large as a small lioness . Even now in the stillness of death , the huge jaws seemed to be dripping with a bluish flame and the small , deep - set , cruel eyes were ringed with fire . " [Phosphorus]170-phosphorus , "[0-i] [I]0-i said .

The front door was open , so [we]1323-we rushed in and hurried from [room]1325-room to room to the amazement of [a doddering old manservant , who met [us]1323-we in [the passage]711-the passage]1326-a doddering old manservant , who met us in the passage . " There 's [someone]1746-someone in [here]1456-here , "[166-lestrade] cried [Lestrade]166-lestrade . " [I]166-lestrade can hear a movement . Open this door ! "[166-lestrade]

A faint moaning and rustling came from within . [Holmes]96-holmes struck the door just over the lock with the flat of [his]96-holmes foot and it flew open . Pistol in hand , [we]1323-we all three rushed into [the room]201-the room .

But there was no sign within [it]201-the room of [that desperate and defiant villain whom [we]1323-we expected to see]1333-that desperate and defiant villain whom we expected to see . Instead [we]1323-we were faced by an object so strange and so unexpected that [we]1323-we stood for a moment staring at [it]1334-it in amazement .

[The room]201-the room had been fashioned into [a small museum]1336-a small museum , and the walls were lined by a number of glass - topped cases full of that collection of butterflies and moths the formation of which had been the relaxation of [this complex and dangerous man]1337-this complex and dangerous man . In the centre of [this room]1760-this room there was an upright beam , which had been placed at some period as a support for the old worm - eaten baulk of timber which spanned the roof . To this post a figure was tied , so swathed and muffled in the sheets which had been used to secure it that [one]1629-one could not for the moment tell whether it was that of [a man]1619-a man or [a woman]1620-a woman . One towel passed round the throat and was secured at the back of the pillar . Another covered the lower part of the face , and over it two dark eyes - eyes full of grief and shame and a dreadful questioning - stared back at [us]1323-we . In a minute [we]1323-we had torn off the gag , unswathed the bonds , and [Mrs. Stapleton]171-stapleton sank upon the floor in front of [us]1323-we . As [her]171-stapleton beautiful head fell upon [her]171-stapleton chest [I]0-i saw the clear red weal of a whiplash across [her]171-stapleton neck .

" [The brute]2634-the brute ! "[96-holmes] cried [Holmes]96-holmes . " Here , [Lestrade]166-lestrade , [your]166-lestrade brandy- bottle ! Put [her]171-stapleton in the chair ! [She]171-stapleton has fainted from ill - usage and exhaustion . "[96-holmes]

And now [I]0-i come rapidly to the conclusion of this singular narrative , in which [I]0-i have tried to make [the reader]1352-the reader share those dark fears and vague surmises which clouded [our]1353-we lives so long and ended in so tragic a manner . [Its]1360-its tenacious grip plucked at [our]1353-we heels as [we]1353-we walked , and when [we]1353-we sank into it it was as if some malignant hand was tugging [us]1353-we down into those obscene depths , so grim and purposeful was the clutch in which it held [us]1353-we . " A dog ! "[96-holmes] said [Holmes]96-holmes . " By [Jove]98-jove , a curly - haired spaniel . [Poor Mortimer]174-poor mortimer will never see [[his]174-poor mortimer pet]2838-his pet again . Chapter 15

A Retrospection

It was the end of November , and [Holmes]96-holmes and [I]0-i sat , upon a raw and foggy night , on either side of a blazing fire in [[our]1384-our sitting- room in [Baker Street]24-baker street]1385-our sitting- room in baker street . Since the tragic upshot of [our]1384-our visit to [Devonshire]10-devonshire [he]1380-he had been engaged in two affairs of the utmost importance , in the first of which [he]1380-he had exposed the atrocious conduct of [Colonel Upwood]175-colonel upwood in connection with the famous card scandal of the Nonpareil Club , while in the second [he]1380-he had defended [the unfortunate Mme . Montpensier]176-the unfortunate mme . montpensier from the charge of murder which hung over [her]1386-her in connection with the death of [[her]1386-her step - daughter]1387-her step - daughter , [Mlle]177-mlle . [Carere]177-mlle , [the young lady who , as it will be remembered]1388-the young lady who , as it will be remembered , was found six months later alive and married in [New York]85-new york . [[My]0-i friend]1476-my friend was in excellent spirits over the success which had attended a succession of difficult and important cases , so that [I]0-i was able to induce [him]1476-my friend to discuss the details of the Baskerville mystery . [I]0-i had waited patiently for the opportunity for [I]0-i was aware that [he]1380-he would never permit cases to overlap , and that [his]1380-he clear and logical mind would not be drawn from its present work to dwell upon memories of the past . [Sir Henry]115-sir henry and [Dr. Mortimer]94-dr. mortimer were , however , in [London]2-london , on [their]1390-i way to that long voyage which had been recommended for the restoration of [his]1380-he shattered nerves . [They]1390-i had called upon [us]1391-us that very after- noon , so that it was natural that [the subject]1392-the subject should come up for discussion .

" The whole course of events , "[96-holmes] said [Holmes]96-holmes , " from the point of view of [the man who called [himself]2853-the man who called himself stapleton [Stapleton]171-stapleton]2853-the man who called himself stapleton was simple and direct , although to [us]1391-us , who had no means in the beginning of knowing the motives of [his]2853-the man who called himself stapleton actions and could only learn part of the facts , it all appeared exceedingly complex . [I]96-holmes have had the advantage of two conversations with [Mrs. Stapleton]171-stapleton , and the case has now been so entirely cleared up that [I]96-holmes am not aware that there is anything which has remained a secret to [us]1391-us . [You]2854-you will find a few notes upon the matter under the heading B in [my]96-holmes indexed list of cases . "[96-holmes]

" Perhaps [you]96-holmes would kindly give [me]1390-i a sketch of the course of events from memory . "[1390-i]

" Certainly , though [I]96-holmes can not guarantee that [I]96-holmes carry all the facts in [my]96-holmes mind . Intense mental concentration has a curious way of blotting out what has passed . [The barrister who has [his]2855-the barrister who has his case at his fingers ' ends and is able to argue with an expert upon his own subject case at [his]2855-the barrister who has his case at his fingers ' ends and is able to argue with an expert upon his own subject fingers ' ends and is able to argue with [an expert]2856-an expert upon [[his]2855-the barrister who has his case at his fingers ' ends and is able to argue with an expert upon his own subject own subject]2857-his own subject]2855-the barrister who has his case at his fingers ' ends and is able to argue with an expert upon his own subject finds that a week or two of the courts will drive it all out of [his]2855-the barrister who has his case at his fingers ' ends and is able to argue with an expert upon his own subject head once more . " [My]1390-i inquiries show beyond all question that [the family]1582-the family por- trait did not lie , and that [this fellow]2383-this fellow was indeed [a Baskerville]115-sir henry . [He]2383-this fellow was [a son of [that Rodger Baskerville]108-rodger]2863-a son of that rodger baskerville , [the younger brother of [Sir Charles]100-sir charles , who fled with a sinister reputation to [South America]63-south america , where [he]100-sir charles was said to have died unmarried]2864-the younger brother of sir charles , who fled with a sinister reputation to south america , where he was said to have died unmarried . [He]2383-this fellow did , as a matter of fact , marry , and had [one child]2865-one child , [this fellow]2383-this fellow , whose real name is the same as [[his]2865-one child father]2551-his father 's . [He]2383-this fellow married [Beryl Garcia]149-beryl , [one of [the beauties of [Costa Rica]86-costa rica]2869-the beauties of costa rica]2868-one of the beauties of costa rica , and , having purloined a considerable sum of public money , [he]2383-this fellow changed [his]2383-this fellow name to [Vandeleur]167-mrs. vandeleur and fled to [England]14-england , where [he]2383-this fellow established [a school in [the east of [Yorkshire]87-yorkshire]2871-the east of yorkshire]2870-a school in the east of yorkshire . [His]2383-this fellow reason for attempting this special line of business was that [he]2383-this fellow had struck up an acquaintance with [a consumptive tutor]2872-a consumptive tutor upon the voyage [home]1520-home , and that [he]2383-this fellow had used [this man]705-this man 's ability to make the undertaking a success . [I]1390-i learned at [the British Museum]2878-the british museum that [he]2383-this fellow was [a recognized authority upon the subject]2879-a recognized authority upon the subject , and that the name of [Vandeleur]167-mrs. vandeleur has been permanently attached to a certain moth which [he]2383-this fellow had , in [his]2383-this fellow [Yorkshire]87-yorkshire days , been the first to describe .[1390-i]

" [We]2880-we now come to that portion of [his]2383-this fellow life which has proved to be of such intense interest to [us]2880-we . [The fellow]823-the fellow had evidently made inquiry and found that only two lives intervened between [him]2383-this fellow and [a valuable estate]2882-a valuable estate . When [he]2383-this fellow went to [Devonshire]10-devonshire [his]2383-this fellow plans were , [I]96-holmes believe , exceedingly hazy , but that [he]2383-this fellow meant mischief from the first is evident from the way in which [he]2383-this fellow took [[his]2383-this fellow wife]1925-his wife with [him]2383-this fellow in the character of [[his]2383-this fellow sister]2032-his sister . [He]2383-this fellow meant in the end to have [the estate]1938-the estate , and [he]2383-this fellow was ready to use any tool or run any risk for that end . [His]2383-this fellow first act was to establish [himself]2383-this fellow as near to [[his]2383-this fellow ancestral home]2887-his ancestral home as [he]2383-this fellow could , and [his]2383-this fellow second was to cultivate a friendship with [Sir Charles Baskerville]100-sir charles and with [the neighbours]545-the neighbours .[96-holmes]

" [The baronet]292-the baronet [himself]292-the baronet told [him]292-the baronet about the family hound , and so prepared the way for [his]2383-this fellow own death . [Stapleton]171-stapleton , as [I]1390-i will continue to call [him]292-the baronet , knew that [the old man]506-the old man 's heart was weak and that a shock would kill [him]506-the old man . So much [he]292-the baronet had learned from [Dr. Morti- mer]120-dr. morti- mer . [He]292-the baronet had heard also that [Sir Charles]100-sir charles was superstitious and had taken this grim legend very seriously . [His]292-the baronet ingenious mind instantly suggested a way by which [the baronet]292-the baronet could be done to death , and yet it would be hardly possible to bring home the guilt to [the real murderer]2892-the real murderer .[1390-i]

" Having conceived the idea [he]292-the baronet proceeded to carry it out with considerable finesse . [An ordinary schemer]2893-an ordinary schemer would have been content to work with a savage hound . The use of artificial means to make the creature diabolical was a flash of genius upon [his]292-the baronet part . The dog [he]292-the baronet bought in [London]2-london from [Ross]180-ross and [Mangles]181-mangles , [the dealers in [Fulham Road]88-fulham road]2894-the dealers in fulham road . [It]2895-it was the strongest and most savage in [their]2894-the dealers in fulham road possession . [He]292-the baronet brought it down by [the North Devon line]2896-the north devon line and walked a great distance over [the moor]1528-the moor so as to get [it]2895-it [home]1520-home without exciting any remarks . [He]292-the baronet had already on [his]292-the baronet insect hunts learned to penetrate the Grimpen Mire , and so had found a safe hiding - place for the creature . Here [he]292-the baronet kennelled [it]2895-it and waited [his]292-the baronet chance .[96-holmes]

" But it was some time coming . [The old gentleman]670-the old gentleman could not be decoyed outside of [[his]292-the baronet grounds]2900-his grounds at night . Several times [Stapleton]171-stapleton lurked about with [his]292-the baronet hound , but without avail . It was during these fruitless quests that [he]292-the baronet , or rather [[his]292-the baronet ally]2901-his ally , was seen by [peasants]2902-peasants , and that the legend of the demon dog received a new confirmation . [He]292-the baronet had hoped that [[his]292-the baronet wife]1925-his wife might lure [Sir Charles]100-sir charles to [his]292-the baronet ruin , but here [she]1925-his wife proved unexpectedly independent . [She]1925-his wife would not endeavour to entangle [the old gentleman]670-the old gentleman in a senti- mental attachment which might deliver [him]292-the baronet over to [[his]292-the baronet enemy]2905-his enemy . [Threats]182-threats and even , [I]1390-i am sorry to say , [blows]2906-blows refused to move [her]1925-his wife . [She]1925-his wife would have nothing to do with it , and for a time [Stapleton]171-stapleton was at a deadlock .[1390-i]

" [He]292-the baronet found a way out of [his]292-the baronet difficulties through the chance that [Sir Charles]100-sir charles , who had conceived a friendship for [him]292-the baronet , made [him]292-the baronet [the minister of [his]292-the baronet charity]2907-the minister of his charity in the case of [this unfortunate woman]2908-this unfortunate woman , [Mrs. Laura Lyons]152-coombe tracey . By representing [himself]292-the baronet as [a single man]2909-a single man [he]292-the baronet acquired complete influence over [her]1925-his wife , and [he]292-the baronet gave [her]1925-his wife to understand.that in the event of [her]1925-his wife obtaining a divorce from [[her]1925-his wife husband]1883-her husband [he]292-the baronet would marry [her]1925-his wife . [His]292-the baronet plans were suddenly brought to a head by [his]292-the baronet knowledge that [Sir Charles]100-sir charles was about to leave [the Hall]1521-the hall on the advice of [Dr. Mortimer]94-dr. mortimer , with whose opinion [he]292-the baronet [himself]292-the baronet pretended to coincide . [He]292-the baronet must act at once , or [[his]292-the baronet victim]2912-his victim might get beyond [his]292-the baronet power . [He]292-the baronet therefore put pressure upon [Mrs. Lyons]152-coombe tracey to write this letter , imploring [the old man]506-the old man to give [her]152-coombe tracey an interview on the evening before [his]292-the baronet departure for [London]2-london . [He]292-the baronet then , by a specious argument , prevented [her]152-coombe tracey from going , and so had the chance for which [he]292-the baronet had waited .[96-holmes]

" Driving back in the evening from [Coombe Tracey]152-coombe tracey [he]292-the baronet was in time to get [his]292-the baronet hound , to treat [it]2914-it with [his]292-the baronet infernal paint , and to bring the beast round to the gate at which [he]292-the baronet had reason to expect that [he]292-the baronet would find [the old gentleman]670-the old gentleman waiting . In [that gloomy tunnel]2919-that gloomy tunnel it must indeed have been a dreadful sight to see that huge black creature , with [its]2914-it flaming jaws and blazing eyes , bounding after its victim . [He]292-the baronet fell dead at the end of [the alley]238-the alley from heart disease and terror . The hound had kept upon [the grassy border]2921-the grassy border while [the baronet]292-the baronet had run down [the path]1632-the path , so that no track but [the man]1397-the man 's was visible . On seeing [him]1397-the man lying still the creature had probably approached to sniff at [him]1397-the man , but finding [him]1397-the man dead had turned away again . It was then that [it]2914-it left the print which was actually observed by [Dr. Mortimer]94-dr. mortimer . " So much for the death of [Sir Charles Baskerville]100-sir charles . [Both of [the women concerned in the case]2933-the women concerned in the case]2932-both of the women concerned in the case , [Mrs. Stapleton]171-stapleton and [Mrs. Laura Lyons]152-coombe tracey , were left with a strong suspicion against [Stapleton]171-stapleton . " It was very essential for [Stapleton]171-stapleton to get some article of [Sir Henry]115-sir henry 's attire so that , in case [he]1397-the man was driven to use the dog , [he]1397-the man might always have the means of setting [him]1397-the man upon [his]1397-the man track . [He]1397-the man then had it returned and obtained another - a most instructive incident , since it proved conclusively to [my]96-holmes mind that [we]2952-we were dealing with a real hound , as no other supposition could explain this anxiety to obtain an old boot and this indifference to a new one . The more outre and grotesque an incident is the more carefully it deserves to be examined , and the very point which appears to complicate a case is , when duly considered and scientifically handled , the one which is most likely to elucidate it .[96-holmes]

" Then [we]2952-we had the visit from [[our]2952-we friends]1816-our friends next morning , shad- owed always by [Stapleton]171-stapleton in [the cab]309-the cab . " [The Stapletons]151-the stapletons then went down to [Devonshire]10-devonshire , whither [they]151-the stapletons were soon followed by [Sir Henry]115-sir henry and [you]2980-you . One word now as to how [I]1393-i stood [myself]1393-i at that time . It may possibly recur to [your]2980-you memory that when [I]1393-i examined the paper upon which the printed words were fastened [I]1393-i made a close inspection for the water- mark . The scent suggested the presence of [a lady]767-a lady , and already [my]1393-i thoughts began to turn towards [the Stapletons]151-the stapletons . " It was [my]96-holmes game to watch [Stapleton]171-stapleton . " [I]1393-i have already told [you]2980-you that [your]2980-you reports reached [me]1393-i rapidly , being forwarded instantly from [Baker Street]24-baker street to [Coombe Tracey]152-coombe tracey . " By the time that [you]2980-you discovered [me]96-holmes upon [the moor]1528-the moor [I]96-holmes had a complete knowledge of the whole business , but [I]96-holmes had not a case which could go to [a jury]2997-a jury . [We]2999-we did so , and at the cost of a severe shock to [[our]2999-we client]3001-our client [we]2999-we succeeded in completing [our]2999-we case and driving [Stapleton]171-stapleton to [his]694-the escaped convict destruction . That [Sir Henry]115-sir henry should have been exposed to this is , [I]96-holmes must confess , a reproach to [my]96-holmes management of the case , but [we]2999-we had no means of foreseeing the terrible and paralyzing spectacle which the beast presented , nor could [we]2999-we predict the fog which enabled [him]694-the escaped convict to burst upon [us]2999-we at such short notice . [We]2999-we succeeded in [our]2999-we object at a cost which both [the specialist]3002-the specialist and [Dr. Mortimer]94-dr. mortimer assure [me]96-holmes will be a tempo- rary one . A long journey may enable [[our]2999-we friend]1718-our friend to recover not only from [his]1718-our friend shattered nerves but also from [his]1718-our friend wounded feel- ings . [His]1718-our friend love for [the lady]590-the lady was deep and sincere , and to [him]1718-our friend the saddest part of all this black business was that [he]1718-our friend should have been deceived by [her]590-the lady .[96-holmes]

" It only remains to indicate the part which [she]590-the lady had played throughout . There can be no doubt that [Stapleton]171-stapleton exercised an influence over [her]590-the lady which may have been love or may have been fear , or very possibly both , since they are by no means incom- patible emotions . It was , at least , absolutely effective . At [his]1718-our friend command [she]590-the lady consented to pass as [[his]1718-our friend sister]2032-his sister , though [he]1718-our friend found the limits of [his]1718-our friend power over [her]590-the lady when [he]1718-our friend endeavoured to make [her]590-the lady the direct accessory to murder . [She]590-the lady was ready to warn [Sir Henry]115-sir henry so far as [she]590-the lady could without implicating [[her]590-the lady husband]1883-her husband , and again and again [she]590-the lady tried to do so . [Stapleton]171-stapleton [himself]171-stapleton seems to have been capable of jealousy , and when [he]1718-our friend saw [the baronet]292-the baronet paying court to [the lady]590-the lady , even though it was part of [his]1718-our friend own plan , still [he]1718-our friend could not help interrupting with a passionate out- burst which revealed the fiery soul which [his]1718-our friend self - contained manner so cleverly concealed . By encouraging the intimacy [he]1718-our friend made it certain that [Sir Henry]115-sir henry would frequently come to [Merripit House]52-merripit house and that [he]115-sir henry would sooner or later get the opportunity which [he]115-sir henry desired . On the day of the crisis , however , [[his]1718-our friend wife]1925-his wife turned suddenly against [him]1718-our friend . [She]1925-his wife had learned something of the death of [the convict]2377-the convict , and [she]1925-his wife knew that the hound was being kept in [the outhouse]3011-the outhouse on the evening that [Sir Henry]115-sir henry was coming to dinner . [She]1925-his wife taxed [[her]1925-his wife husband]1883-her husband with [his]1718-our friend intended crime , and a furious scene followed in which [he]1718-our friend showed [her]1925-his wife for the first time that [she]1925-his wife had [a rival in [his]1718-our friend love]3013-a rival in his love . [Her]1925-his wife fidelity turned in an instant to bitter hatred , and [he]1718-our friend saw that [she]1925-his wife would betray [him]1718-our friend . [He]1718-our friend tied [her]1925-his wife up , therefore , that [she]1925-his wife might have no chance of warning [Sir Henry]115-sir henry , and [he]1718-our friend hoped , no doubt , that when [the whole countryside]2270-the whole countryside put down [the baronet]292-the baronet 's death to the curse of [[his]1718-our friend family]1605-his family , as [they]1605-his family certainly would do , [he]1718-our friend could win [[his]1718-our friend wife]1925-his wife back to accept an accomplished fact and to keep silent upon what [she]1925-his wife knew . In this [I]1393-i fancy that in any case [he]1718-our friend made a miscalculation , and that , if [we]3018-we had not been [there]1461-there , [his]1718-our friend doom would none the less have been sealed . [A woman of Spanish blood]3020-a woman of spanish blood does not condone such an irjury so lightly . " [He]1718-our friend could not hope to frighten [Sir Henry]115-sir henry to death as [he]1718-our friend had done [the old uncle]3022-the old uncle with [his]3022-the old uncle bogie hound . "[96-holmes]

" The beast was savage and half - starved . If its appearance did not frighten [its victim]1316-its victim to death , at least it would paralyze the resistance which might be offered . "[1393-i]

" No doubt . There only remains one difficulty . If [Stapleton]171-stapleton came into the succession , how could [he]1718-our friend explain the fact that [he]1718-our friend , [the heir]1661-the heir , had been living unannounced under another name so close to [the property]1954-the property ? How could [he]1718-our friend claim it without causing suspicion and inquiry ? "[96-holmes]

" It is a fomlidable difficulty , and [I]1393-i fear that [you]95-watson ask too much when [you]95-watson expect [me]1393-i to solve it . The past and the present are within the field of [my]1393-i inquiry , but what [a man]1619-a man may do in the future is a hard question to answer . [Mrs. Stapleton]171-stapleton has heard [[her]171-stapleton husband]1883-her husband discuss the problem on several occasions . There were three possible courses . [He]1718-our friend might claim [the property]1954-the property from [South America]63-south america , establish [his]1718-our friend identity before [the British authorities]3029-the british authorities [there]1461-there and so obtain the fortune without ever coming to [England]14-england at all , or [he]1718-our friend might adopt an elaborate disguise during the short time that [he]1718-our friend need be in [London]2-london ; or , again , [he]1718-our friend might furnish [an accomplice]3031-an accomplice with the proofs and papers , putting [him]1718-our friend in as [heir]3032-heir , and retaining a claim upon some proportion of [his]1718-our friend income .
